Prose Introduction.quote:
About Ægir and the Gods

Ægir, who by another name was called Gymir, had brewed ale for the Æsir, after he had received the great cauldron, as has now been said.

To that feast came Óðinn and Frigg, his wife. Þórr did not come, because he was on the east-way. Sif, Þórr’s wife, was there, and Bragi and Iðunn, his wife. Týr was there. He was one-handed: Fenrisúlfr bit off his hand when he was bound. Njǫrðr was there, as was his wife, Skaði, Freyr and Freyja, [and] Víðarr, Óðinn’s son. Loki was there, and Freyr’s servants, Byggvir and Beyla. Many of the Æsir and elves were there.

Ægir had two serving-men, Fimafengr and Eldir. Shining gold was used there instead of firelight. Ale served itself there. It was a great place of sanctuary. People were full of praise for how good Ægir’s serving-men were. Loki could not bear to hear that, and he slew Fimafengr.

Then the Æsir shook their shields and screamed at Loki, and chased him away to the forest, and they went to drink. Loki turned back and met Eldir outside.

Summary.explanation: The entire narrative of the poem concerns Baldr, narrating how Odin speaks to a dead volva about Baldr’s fate. Baldr, son of Odin, is plagued by terrible nightmares foretelling his own death. Worried, Odin rides his steed, Sleipnir, to Hel to seek answers. He finds the grave of a dead seeress (völva) and resurrects her with magic. In disguise, Odin questions her and learns that the halls of Hel are being prepared for Baldr. The seeress reveals Baldr will be killed by his blind brother, Hǫðr. She then prophesies that Váli will be born to avenge Baldur's death. After the seeress recognizes him, Odin returns to Asgard with the grim knowledge of his son's fate.

Hyndluljóð (The Lay of Hyndla).Note: Since the entire narrative revolves around Freyja, I recommend reading the whole poem. Only a summarization of the poem is given here.

Summary.explanation: The goddess Freyja awakens the giantess and seeress, Hyndla, demanding her help. Freyja has brought along her human favorite, Óttar. She commands the reluctant Hyndla to recite Óttar's complete family tree so he can claim his inheritance. Hyndla recites a vast genealogy, listing famous heroes, kings, and even gods to establish Óttar's noble ancestry. This recitation is interrupted by a separate, shorter prophecy about the events of Ragnarök. After finishing the lineage, Hyndla tries to give Óttar a poisoned "ale of forgetfulness." Freyja outwits the jötunn woman, protecting Óttar with magic and giving him a "memory-ale" instead, ensuring he remembers his heritage.

Summary.explanation: The goddess Freyja awakens the giantess and seeress, Hyndla, demanding her help. Freyja has brought along her human favorite, Óttar. She commands the reluctant Hyndla to recite Óttar's complete family tree so he can claim his inheritance. Hyndla recites a vast genealogy, listing famous heroes, kings, and even gods to establish Óttar's noble ancestry. This recitation is interrupted by a separate, shorter prophecy about the events of Ragnarök. After finishing the lineage, Hyndla tries to give Óttar a poisoned "ale of forgetfulness." Freyja outwits the jötunn woman, protecting Óttar with magic and giving him a "memory-ale" instead, ensuring he remembers his heritage.

Chapter 75 (p.157).quote: Now shall all the Asyniur be named. Frigg and Freyia, Fulla and Snotra, Gerd and Gefiun, Gna, Lofn, Skadi, Iord and Idunn, Ilm, Bil, Niorun.

Chapter 25-27 (p.25).quote: He has a trumpet called Giallarhorn and its blast can be heard in all worlds.

Chapter 51 (p.54).explanation: It is foretold that Heimdall will sound Gjallarhorn to awaken the gods at the beginning of Ragnarok.

Chapter 35 (p.30-31).explanation: Gna is listed as the fourteenth Asynia. She is Frigg's messenger and rides her horse Hofvarpnir across the sky and sea.
Chapter 35 (p.30-31).quote:
Fourteenth Gna: she is sent by Frigg into various worlds to carry out her business. She has a horse that gallops across sky and sea, called Hofvarpnir. It happened once as she was riding that some Vanir saw her travelling through the sky.

Stanza 1.quote:

greater and lesser, the sons of Heimdallr!

ancient tales of the living, those which I recall from longest ago.

Stanza 27.quote:

hidden under the light-accustomed holy tree;
she sees a river splashing in a muddy fall
from Valfǫðr’s pledge. Would you know still [more], or what?

there the gods’ watchman drinks in a homely hall,
glad, the good mead.

Stanza 47-48.quote:

48. ‘Silence, Heimdallr! In early days

with a muddy back you’ll always be,

Stanza 15-16.explanation: Heimdallr offers the wise counsel that solves the gods' dilemma of how to retrieve Thor's hammer.
Stanza 15-16.quote:

he knew the future well, like other Vanir:

Prose Introduction.explanation: The prose introduction to the poem explicitly identifies the protagonist, Rígr, as Heimdallr.
Prose Introduction.quote: People say thus in ancient stories, that a certain one of the Æsir, the one who was called Heimdallr, went on his travels and, advancing along a certain sea-strand, came to a farmstead and named himself Rígr. This poem is based on that story:

Narrative Summary.explanation: The poem then narrates how Rígr (Heimdallr) visits three households. In each, he sleeps between the husband and wife for three nights. Nine months later, a son is born in each home: Thrall (progenitor of the serfs), Karl (progenitor of the free farmers), and Jarl (progenitor of the aristocracy). Heimdallr is thus presented as the father of the three classes of mankind.
Narrative Summary.note: Even though the introduction names Heimdallr as Rig, the poem makes no reference to Heimdallr, and some scholars think the poem is actually about Odin. Voluspa stanza 1 seems to agree with Rig being Heimdallr.

Chapter 25-27 (p.25).explanation: This chapter provides the most detailed description of Heimdallr.
Chapter 25-27 (p.25).quote: ‘Heimdall is the name of one. He is known as the white As. He is great and holy. Nine maidens bore him as their son, all of them sisters. He is also called Hallinskidi and Gullintanni: his teeth were of gold. His horse is called Gulltopp. He lives in a place called Himinbiorg by Bifrost. He is the gods’ watchman and sits there at the edge of heaven to guard the bridge against mountain-giants. He needs less sleep than a bird. He can see, by night just as well as by day, a distance of a hundred leagues. He can also hear grass growing on the earth and wool on sheep and everything that sounds louder than that. Chapter 51 (p.54).quote: And when these events take place, Heimdall will stand up and blow mightily on Giallarhorn and awaken all the gods and they will hold a parliament together. [...] Loki will have a battle with Heimdall and they will cause each other’s death.

Introduction (p.59).explanation: Heimdallr is listed among the twelve Æsir designated as judges.
Introduction (p.59).quote: Then the Æsir instituted their banquet and twelve Æsir who were to be judges took their places in their thrones and their names are as follows: Thor, Niord, Freyr, Tyr, Heimdall, Bragi, Vidar, Vali, Uli, Hænir, Forseti, Loki...

Chapter 2 (p.68).explanation: Heimdallr is described as riding to Baldr's funeral pyre.
Chapter 2 (p.68).quote: Splendid Heimdall rides to the pyre raised by gods for the fallen son [Baldr] of the strangely wise raven-tester [Odin], on his horse.

The entire poem is about Loki insulting.explanation: Loki, uninvited, goes to a great feast hosted by Ægir for the Æsir gods. He engages in a "flyting," or a ritual exchange of insults, with each god and goddess present. Loki systematically exposes their most shameful secrets, accusing the gods of cowardice and unmanliness, and the goddesses of man-eagerness. The gods are unable to silence him with words, as Loki counters every defense with another sharp accusation. The confrontation only ends when Thor arrives, late to the feast. Thor threatens him with his hammer, Mjölnir. Loki finally departs, but not before delivering a final curse, having shattered the fellowship of the gods and sealed his own fate.

The poem is about Thor and Loki recoveri.explanation: Thor wakes up and finds his hammer Mjolnir missing and tells Loki first. Loki goes to Freyja, which gladly lends him her falcon form. Loki flies to jotunheimr, and finds Þrymr, which admits that he stole and hid the hammer. Þrymr ask for Freyja in marriage in exchange for the hammer. Loki goes back and tells the news to Thor. Both tell Freyja to prepare to go to jotunheimr. She refuses. Heimdallr propose a different plan, to send Thor in disguise as Freyja. Which Thor accepts because of the danger of missing his hammer. Loki and Thor go to Þrymr for the wedding. Thor behaves nothing like a bride, which makes Þrymr suspicious, but Loki explains it away. Once Þrymr brings Mjolnir to consecrate the marriage, Thor grabs it and kills everyone in attendance.

[...] And when the stallion realized what kind of horse it was, it went frantic and tore apart the tackle and ran towards the mare, and she away to the wood... But Loki had had such dealings with Svadilfæri that somewhat later he gave birth to a foal. It was grey and had eight legs, and this is the best horse among gods and men.

Chapter 43-44 (p.37).explanation: Loki accompanies Thor on his journey to the court of Utgarda-Loki.
Chapter 43-44 (p.37).quote: ‘The beginning of this business is that Oku-Thor set off with his goats and chariot and with him the As called Loki. In the evening they arrived at a peasant’s house...

Chapter 46 (p.41).explanation: Loki competes in an eating contest against a figure named Logi and loses.
Chapter 46 (p.41).quote: ‘Then the one who was in the rear of the party, which was Loki, said: ‘ “I know a feat that I am quite prepared to have a go at, that there is no one inside here who can eat his food quicker than I.” [...] Loki had then eaten all the meat off the bones, but Logi had also eaten all the meat and the bones too and also the trencher, and it seemed to everyone now that Loki had lost the contest.

Chapter 47 (p.45).explanation: Utgarda-Loki explains that Loki's opponent, Logi, was an illusion representing wildfire itself.
Chapter 47 (p.45).quote: ‘The first was the one that Loki engaged in. He was very hungry and ate fast, but the one who is called Logi [flame], that was wildfire, and it burned the trencher just as quickly as the meat.

Chapter 49 (p.48-49).explanation: Loki engineers the death of Baldr by discovering the mistletoe's exception from the oaths, fashioning a weapon from it, and tricking the blind god Hod into throwing it.
Chapter 49 (p.48-49).quote: But when Loki Laufeyiarson saw this he was not pleased that Baldr was unharmed. [...] And Loki took mistletoe and plucked it and went to the assembly. Hod was standing at the edge of the circle of people, for he was blind. Then Loki said to him: ‘ “Why are you not shooting at Baldr?” [...] “Follow other people’s example and do Baldr honour like other people. I will direct you to where he is standing. Shoot at him this stick.”

Chapter 49-50 (p.51-52).explanation: For his crimes, the Æsir hunt Loki down. He is captured and bound in a cave with the entrails of his son, while a snake drips venom on him.
Chapter 49-50 (p.51-52).quote: ‘Now Loki was captured without quarter and taken to a certain cave. Then they took three stone slabs and set them on edge and knocked a hole in each slab. [...] Then the Æsir took his guts and bound Loki with them across the three stones [...] Then Skadi got a poisonous snake and fixed it up over him so that the poison would drip from the snake into his face. But his wife Sigyn stands next to him holding a basin under the drops of poison. [...] There he will lie in bonds until Ragnarok.’

Chapter 51 (p.54).explanation: Loki's role in Ragnarok is foretold, where he will arrive with the forces of Hel and fight Heimdall to their mutual deaths.
Chapter 51 (p.54).quote: By then Loki will also have arrived there and Hrym and with him all the frost-giants, but with Loki will be all Hel’s people. [...] Loki will have a battle with Heimdall and they will cause each other’s death.

Introduction (p.59-61).explanation: Loki is listed among the Æsir at Ægir's feast. Bragi's first story recounts how Loki, to save his own life from the giant Thjazi, lured the goddess Idunn out of Asgard for the giant to abduct. When the gods began to age, they threatened Loki with death, forcing him to rescue her.
Introduction (p.59-61).quote: Then Loki was arrested and brought to the parliament and he was threatened with death or torture. Being filled with terror, he said he would go in search of Idunn in Giantland if Freyia would lend him a falcon shape of hers. And when he got the falcon shape he flew north to Giantland...

Chapter 8-16 (p.76-77).explanation: When listing kennings for Heimdall, one is "Loki’s enemy". Kennings for Loki himself are then detailed.
Chapter 8-16 (p.76-77).quote:
How shall Heimdall be referred to? By calling him [...] Loki’s enemy...

How shall Loki be referred to? By calling him son of Farbauti and Laufey, of Nal, brother of Byleist and Helblindi, father of Vanargand, i.e. Fenriswolf, and of Iormungand, i.e. the Midgard serpent, and Hel’s and Nari’s and Ali’s relative and father, brother, comrade and table-companion of Odin and the Æsir, Geirrod’s visitor and casket-ornament, thief from giants, of goat and Brisingamen and Idunn’s apples, relative of Sleipnir, husband of Sigyn, enemy of gods, Sif’s hair-harmer, maker of mischief, the cunning As, accuser and tricker of the gods, contriver of Baldr’s death, the bound one, wrangler with Heimdall and Skadi.

Chapter 17-18 (p.81).explanation: The tale of Thor's visit to Geirrod begins because of Loki. Having been captured by the giant Geirrod, Loki agrees to lure Thor to the giant's court without his protective gear in exchange for his life.
Chapter 17-18 (p.81).quote: The story of how Thor went to Geirrod’s courts is worth detailed treatment. On that occasion he did not have the hammer Miollnir or the girdle of might or the iron gauntlets, and that was Loki’s doing. [...] to redeem his life he swore Geirrod oaths that he would get Thor to come to Geirrod’s courts without his bringing either his hammer or girdle of might.

Chapter 22 (p.87-88).explanation: The poem Haustlǫng is quoted, which retells the story of Idunn's abduction and Loki's role in both her capture and rescue.
Chapter 22 (p.87-88).quote: Then the burden of Sigyn’s arms [Loki], whom all the powers eye in his bonds, got stuck to the ski-deity’s [Skadi’s] fosterer [father, Thiassi]. The pole clung to the mighty haunter of Giantland and the hands of Hænir’s good friend [Loki] to the end of the rod.

Chapter 32-33 (p.95).explanation: During the feast at Ægir's hall that provides the frame for the book's dialogue, Loki's malice is mentioned.
Chapter 32-33 (p.95).quote: Then Loki wrangled with all the gods there and killed a slave of Ægir’s called Fimafeng.

Chapter 34-35 (p.96-97).explanation: The story of the creation of the gods' greatest treasures begins with one of Loki's malicious acts.
Chapter 34-35 (p.96-97).quote:
Why is gold called Sif’s hair? Loki Laufeyiarson had done this for love of mischief: he had cut off all Sif’s hair.

After wagering his head with the dwarf Brokk that his brother Eitri could not forge treasures as fine as those made by the sons of Ivaldi, Loki loses the bet. To escape decapitation, he argues that the dwarf won his head, but not his neck. Brokk instead sews Loki's lips shut.

Chapter 37-39 (p.99-100).explanation: While traveling with Odin and Hœnir, Loki carelessly kills an otter, which is revealed to be the son of the magician Hreidmar. To ransom their lives, the gods must cover the otter's skin with gold.
Chapter 37-39 (p.99-100).quote: Then Loki picked up a stone and threw it at the otter and hit its head. Then Loki was triumphant at his catch, that he had got in one blow otter and salmon. [...] Then Odin sent Loki into the world of black-elves and he came across a dwarf called Andvari. [...] and imposed on him as a ransom all the gold he had in his cave. [...] the dwarf pronounced that this ring should be the deadly destruction of whoever possessed it.

Chapter 40-41 (p.102).explanation: The cursed ring Loki took from Andvari is mentioned as a morning-gift given by Sigurd to Brynhild.
Chapter 40-41 (p.102).quote: And in the morning when he got up and dressed, he gave Brynhild as morning gift the gold ring that Loki had taken from Andvari, and received from her another ring as keepsake.

Chapter 75 (p.157).explanation: Loki is named last in a list of the Æsir.
Chapter 75 (p.157).quote: Yet shall be listed names of Æsir. There is Ygg and Thor and Yngvi-Freyr, Vidar and Baldr, Vali and Heimdall. Then there is Tyr and Niord, I list Bragi next, Hod, Forseti. Here is Loki last.

Stanza 52.explanation: Móði and Magni will possess Thor’s hammer, Mjöllnir after Ragnarok.
Stanza 52.quote:
‘Víðarr and Váli will settle in the gods’ sanctuaries
when the dark flame dies;
Móði and Magni will have Mjǫllnir
and work at the war’s end.

Chapter 52-53 (p.56).explanation: After Ragnarok, Magni and Modi will survive and inherit their father's hammer, Miollnir.
Chapter 52-53 (p.56).quote:
‘And then Thor’s sons Modi and Magni will arrive, bringing Miollnir. After that Baldr and Hod will arrive from Hel. [...]
 
 Vidar and Vali will dwell in the gods’ holy places when Surt’s flame goes dark. Modi and Magni shall have Miollnir when Vingnir fights no more.

Chapter 3-4 (p.72).explanation: Thor can be referred to by kennings as the father of Magni.
Chapter 3-4 (p.72).quote:
How shall Thor be referred to? By calling him son of Odin and lord, father of Magni and Modi and Thrud...

Roskva’s brother [Thialfi] stood enraged, Magni’s father struck a victorious blow. Neither Thor nor Thialfi’s power-stone [heart] shakes with terror.

Chapter 17 (p.79).explanation: Magni, at three years old, arrives after Thor's duel with Hrungnir and is the only one strong enough to lift the jötun's leg off of Thor.
Chapter 17 (p.79).quote:
Then Magni, son of Thor and Iarnsaxa, arrived. He was then three years old. He threw Hrung­nir’s leg off Thor and said:

‘Isn’t it a terrible shame, father, that I arrived so late. I think I would have knocked this giant into Hel with my fist if I had come across him.’

Stanza 5.explanation: Máni is mentioned as companion of Sól.
Stanza 5.quote:
‘Sól, companion of Máni, cast from the south
her right hand over the sky-horse-deer(?);
Sól did not know where she had halls,
stars did not know where they had stations,
Máni did not know what might he had

Stanza 22-23.explanation: Óðinn asks Vafþrúðnir where Sól and Máni come from.
Stanza 22-23.quote:
Óðinn said:
22. ‘Say this secondly, if your mind is strong
and you, Vafþrúðnir, know:
whence Máni came, so that he journeys over men,
and Sól the same.’

Vafþrúðnir said:
23. ‘He’s called Mundilfæri, he’s the father of Máni,
and of Sól the same;
they must turn the sky each day,
as a year-reckoning for men.

Stanza 39.explanation: The wolf Hati pursues the moon.
Stanza 39.quote:
‘Skǫll is the name of the wolf which pursues the shiny-faced god
to the shelter of the wood;
and the other, Hati, he is Hróðvitnir’s son,
he must be before the shining bride of the sky.

Stanza 13-14.explanation: Thor asks Alvíss the different names of the moon.
Stanza 13-14.quote:
13. ‘Tell me this, Alvíss — I expect, dwarf, that you know
all the history of living beings:
how the moon, which men see,
is named in each world.’

14. ‘It’s named máni37 among men, but mýlinn38 among gods,
in Hel they call it hverfanda hvél,
giants skyndir, and dwarves skin,
elves call it ártali.’

Chapter 10-12 (p.14).explanation: Mani is introduced as the son of Mundilfæri and brother of Sol. The gods set him in the sky to guide the moon's course. He took two children from the earth, Bil and Hjúki, who accompany him. He is pursued by the wolf Hati.
Chapter 10-12 (p.14).quote:
‘There was a person whose name was Mundilfaeri who had two children. They were so fair and beautiful that he called the one Moon and his daughter Sol [sun]... Moon guides the course of the moon and controls its waxing and waning. He took two children from the earth called Bil and Hiuki... These children go with Moon, as can be seen from earth.’

‘...and the one that is running ahead of her is called Hati Hrodvitnisson, and he is trying to catch the moon, and that will happen.’

Chapter 25-29 (p.93).explanation: A kenning for the sun is "sister of Moon", and a verse by Skuli Thorsteinsson mentions the moon.
Chapter 25-29 (p.93).quote:
How shall the sun be referred to? By calling it daughter of Mundilfæri, sister of Moon...

God-blithe bedfellow of Glen steps to her divine sanctuary with brightness; then descends the good light of grey-clad moon.

Chapter 51 (p.125).explanation: A verse is quoted from the Icelandic poet Mani, who is a separate figure from the god.
Chapter 51 (p.125).quote:
Otter, as Mani said:

What will you, slouching, grey-cheeked old man, be able to do with the fellows on the ocean-otter? For your strength is fading.

Chapter 56-57 (p.134).explanation: A list of poetic synonyms (heiti) for the Moon is provided.
Chapter 56-57 (p.134).quote: Moon: lune, waxer, waner, year-counter, clipped, shiner, gloam, hastener, squinter, gleamer.

Stanza 9.explanation: Thor declares his name and lineage, naming Meili as his brother.
Stanza 9.quote:
Þórr said:
‘I would tell my name, even if I were outlawed,
and all my lineage, too: I am Óðinn’s son,
Meili’s brother and Magni’s father,
strong-ruler of gods — it’s Þórr you’re speaking to here!
Now I want to ask this, what you are called.’

Chapter 17 (p.80).explanation: In a verse from Haustlǫng, Thor is referred to by the kenning "Meili's brother".
Chapter 17 (p.80).quote: The son of Iord drove to the game of iron [battle] and the moon’s way [sky] thundered beneath him. Wrath swelled in Meili’s brother [Thor].

Chapter 22 (p.87).explanation: Hænir is referred to by the kenning "step-Meili".
Chapter 22 (p.87).quote: The mountain-wolf [giant] asked step-Meili [Hænir] to share out to him his fill from the holy table.

Chapter 23 (p.89).explanation: In a verse by Thiodolf of Hvinir, Thor is again referred to by the kenning "Meili's brother".
Chapter 23 (p.89).quote: Iord’s son drove to iron-game [battle], and the moon’s way thundered under him. Meili’s brother’s rage swelled.

Chapter 75 (p.156).explanation: Meili is listed as a son of Odin, and thus brother of Thor.
Chapter 75 (p.156).quote: Odin’s sons are Baldr and Meili, Vidar and Nep, Vali, Ali, Thor and Hildolf, Hermod, Sigi, Skiold, Yngvi-Freyr and Itreksiod, Heimdall, Sæming.

Stanza 28.explanation: Mímir and his well are mentioned in relation to the eye Óðinn gave for a drink of the well.
Stanza 28.quote:
‘Alone she sat outside when the old one came,
Yggjungr of the Æsir, and looked into her eyes:
“What do you ask me? Why do you test me?
I know it all, Óðinn, where you hid your eye,
in the famous spring of Mímir;
Mímir drinks mead every morning
from Valfǫðr’s pledge!” Would you know still [more], or what?

Stanza 45.explanation: Mímir is mentioned in relation to Ragnarok, when Óðinn goes to him for counsel.
Stanza 45.quote:
‘Mímr’s sons play, and destiny is kindled
at [the sound of?] the resonant Gjallarhorn;
Heimdallr blows loud — the horn’s aloft —
Óðinn speaks to Mímr’s head.

Stanza 14.explanation: Mímir’s head is said to have spoken.
Stanza 14.quote:
‘On a cliff he stood with Brimir’s edges,
he had a helmet on his head;
then Mímr’s head spoke
wisely the first word
and said true staves.

Fjǫlsvinnsmál Stanza 20.explanation: Yggdrasil is referred to as Mímameiðr.
Fjǫlsvinnsmál Stanza 20.quote:
‘It’s called Mímameiðr, but few know it,
from what roots it runs;
it will fall by that which the fewest expect —
neither fire nor iron will flay it.

Fjǫlsvinnsmál Stanza 24.explanation: Yggdrasil is referred to as “tree of Mími”.
Fjǫlsvinnsmál Stanza 24.quote:
‘He’s called Viðófnir, and he stands on Veðrglasir,
on twigs of the tree of Mími;
with one sorrow he oppresses immeasurably
Surtr’s Sinmara.

Chapter 15 (p.17).explanation: Mimir is introduced as the guardian of a well of wisdom that lies beneath one of the roots of Yggdrasil. To drink from it, Odin had to sacrifice his eye.
Chapter 15 (p.17).quote:
But under the root that reaches towards the frost-giants, there is where Mimir’s well is, which has wisdom and intelligence contained in it, and the master of the well is called Mimir. He is full of learning because he drinks of the well from the horn Giallarhorn. All-father went there and asked for a single drink from the well, but he did not get one until he placed his eye as a pledge. Thus it says in Völuspá:

I know it all, Odin, where you deposited your eye, in that renowned well of Mimir. Mimir drinks mead every morn­ing from Val-father’s pledge. Know you yet, or what?

Chapter 51 (p.54).explanation: Before the battle of Ragnarok, it is foretold that Odin will ride to Mimir's well for counsel. In a quoted verse from Völuspá, it is said that Odin speaks with "Mim's head."
Chapter 51 (p.54).quote:
Then Odin will ride to Mimir’s well and consult Mimir on his own and his people’s behalf.


Loud blows Heimdall, his horn is aloft. Odin speaks with Mim’s head.

Chapter 2 (p.68).explanation: In a verse by Egil Skallagrimsson, Odin is referred to by the kenning "Mim's friend".
Chapter 2 (p.68).quote: I do not worship Vilir’s brother [Odin], god of earth, because I am eager; yet has Mim’s friend [Odin] granted me a grief-comforter...

Chapter 3 (p.71).explanation: In a verse by Volu-Stein, poetry is referred to by a kenning that uses "Mim's friend" for Odin.
Chapter 3 (p.71).quote: Hear, Egil, my streams [the mead] of Mim’s friend’s [Odin’s] joy-hill [breast] echo against gum-skerries [teeth].

Chapter 18 (p.112).explanation: The name "Mimir" is used as a base word in a kenning for a giant ("Mischief-Mimir").
Chapter 18 (p.112).quote: Mischief-Mimir’s [giant’s] widows [Gialp and Greip] made the harsh current violent against the pole.

Chapter 54-56 (p.133).explanation: The name "Mimir" is used as a base word in kennings for the heavens ("storm-Mimir", "winter-Mimir").
Chapter 54-56 (p.133).quote: The following names for the heavens are written down, but we have not found all these terms in poems. But these poetical terms like others seem to me not proper to include in poetry unless one finds similar terms already in the work of major poets: heaven, twin-lit, clouded-brightness, storm-Mimir, Andlang, light-bringer, sprinkler, rich-wetter, wide-embracer, winter-Mimir...

Chapter 57-58 (p.135).explanation: In a systematic list of names for giants, Mimir is included.
Chapter 57-58 (p.135).quote: I shall tell the names of giants. Ymir, Gang and Mimir, Idi and Thiassi, Hrungnir, Hrimnir, Hraudnir, Grimnir...

Chapter 75 (p.159).explanation: In a list of names for a sword, one is "flesh-Mimir".
Chapter 75 (p.159).quote: Keen, head-sharp, skull-crusher, corpse-Gaut, host-shining and flesh-Mimir, wound-strip, deceiver, flickerer, rivet-failer, burnished, heaper, notched, gate-flame.

Chapter 75 (p.164).explanation: In a list of poetic names for the heavens, the name "Mimir" is used as a base-word in the terms Hregg-Mimir (storm-Mimir) and Vet-Mimir (winter-Mimir).
Chapter 75 (p.164).quote:
There
are nine heavens on high that are listed. I know the nethermost, it is 
Vindblain [wind-dark], it is Heidthornir [clouded-brightness] and 
Hregg-Mimir [storm-Mimir]. [...] Gimir [fiery or jewelled], Vet-Mimir 
[winter-Mimir].

Stanza 51.explanation: Thor is not named, but his sons Móði and Magni will possess his hammer, Mjöllnir after Ragnarok.
Stanza 51.quote:
‘Víðarr and Váli will settle in the gods’ sanctuaries
when the dark flame dies;
Móði and Magni will have Mjǫllnir
and work at the war’s end.

Stanza 36.explanation: After gaining a tremendous cauldron that the jötunn (and personified ocean) Ægir has requested so that he may brew the gods ale, Thor battles malicious jötnar with the hammer.
Stanza 36.quote:
He heaved the [high-]standing cauldron from his shoulders,
he swung murder-eager Mjǫllnir forward,
and he slew all the lava-whales.

Stanzas 57 to 64.explanation: Thor arrives late at Ægir's feast and immediately threatens Loki with his hammer, Mjöllnir. He exchanges threats with Loki until Loki flees the hall.
Stanzas 57 to 64.quote:
Then Þórr arrived and said:
57. ‘Silence, perverted creature! My power-hammer,
Mjǫllnir, shall deprive you of speech;
I’ll knock the crag of the shoulders off your neck,
and then your life will be gone!’

Loki said:
58. ‘Jǫrð’s son has now come in here —
why are you so aggressive, Þórr?
But you won’t be daring then, when you ought to fight against the wolf,
and he swallows Sigfaðir whole!’

Þórr said:
59. ‘Silence, perverted creature! My power-hammer,
Mjǫllnir, shall deprive you of speech;
I’ll hurl you up and onto the east-way,
No one will see you again!’

Loki said:
60. ‘Your eastern journeys you ought never
to tell people about,
since, unique champion, you cowered in the thumb of a glove,
and you didn’t seem to be Þórr then!’

Þórr said:
61. ‘Silence, perverted creature! My power-hammer,
Mjǫllnir, shall deprive you of speech;
with my right hand I’ll strike you with Hrungnir’s slayer,
so that all your bones will be broken!’

Loki said:
62. ‘For myself, I intend to live a long life,
though you threaten me with your hammer;
Skrýmir’s straps seemed hard to you,
and you couldn’t get your supplies then,
and you were dying of hunger, [though] healthy!’

Þórr said:
63. ‘Silence, perverted creature! My power-hammer,
Mjǫllnir, shall deprive you of speech;
Hrungnir’s slayer will send you to Hel,
down below corpse-gates!’

Loki said:
64. ‘I have said before the Æsir, I have said before the sons of the Æsir,
that which my disposition incited me to;
but for you alone will I go out,
because I know that you attack!

Stanza 1-2-3.explanation: Thor wakes up and finds out his hammer is missing. Then tells Loki about it, which ask Freyja for her feather-skin to recover the hammer.
Stanza 1-2-3.quote:
1. Angry then was Vingþórr, when he awoke
and missed his hammer;
his beard shuddered, his hair shook,
Jǫrð’s son groped around himself.

2. And he spoke these words first of all:
‘Listen now, Loki, to what I now say,
it’s unknown anywhere on earth
or in sky above — the Áss has been robbed of his hammer!’

3. They went to fair Freyja’s dwellings,
and he spoke these words first of all:
‘Will you lend me your feather-skin, Freyja,
[to see] if I can find my hammer?’

Chapter 20-21 (p.22).explanation: Mjöllnir is introduced as one of Thor's three most prized possessions.
Chapter 20-21 (p.22).quote: One of them is the hammer Miollnir, well known to frost-giants and mountain-giants when it is raised aloft, and that is not to be wondered at: it has smashed many a skull for their fathers and kinsmen.

Chapter 42-43 (p.36).explanation: When the gods call upon Thor to deal with the giant builder, he uses Mjöllnir to kill him.
Chapter 42-43 (p.36).quote: ...and the next thing was that Miollnir was raised aloft. Then he paid the builder’s wages and it wasn’t the sun and moon, instead he stopped him from living in Giantland and struck the first blow so that his skull was shattered into fragments...

Chapter 44-45 (p.38).explanation: Thor uses Mjöllnir to hallow and resurrect his goats after they have been eaten.
Chapter 44-45 (p.38).quote: ...took the hammer Miollnir and raised it and blessed the goatskins. Then the goats got up and one of them was lame in the hind leg.

Chapter 45 (p.39).explanation: While traveling, Thor attempts to kill the giant Skrýmir in his sleep by striking him with Mjöllnir.
Chapter 45 (p.39).quote: And when he realized that this labour was going to get nowhere, he got angry, grasped the hammer Miollnir in both hands and stepped forward with one foot to where Skrymir was lying and struck at his head.

Chapter 48 (p.47).explanation: During the fishing trip, after the giant Hymir cuts the line, Thor throws his hammer at the escaping Midgard Serpent.
Chapter 48 (p.47).quote: But Thor threw his hammer after it, and they say that he struck off its head by the sea-bed.

Chapter 49 (p.49).explanation: At Baldr's funeral, Thor hallows the pyre with his hammer.
Chapter 49 (p.49).quote: Then Thor stood by and consecrated the pyre with Miollnir.

Chapter 52-53 (p.56).explanation: It is prophesied that after Ragnarok, Thor's sons Modi and Magni will inherit Mjöllnir.
Chapter 52-53 (p.56).quote:
And then Thor’s sons Modi and Magni will arrive, bringing Miollnir.

[...]

Modi and Magni shall have Miollnir when Vingnir fights no more.

Chapter 3-4 (p.72).explanation: A kenning for Thor is "ruler and owner of Miollnir."
Chapter 3-4 (p.72).quote: How shall Thor be referred to? By calling him son of Odin and Iord, father of Magni and Modi and Thrud, husband of Sif, stepfather of Uli, ruler and owner of Miollnir and the girdle of might, of Bilskirnir, defender of Asgard, Midgard, enemy and slayer of giants and troll-wives, killer of Hrungnir, Geirrod, Thrivaldi, lord of Thialfi and Roskva, enemy of the Midgard serpent, foster-son of Vingnir and Hlora.

Chapter 4 (p.73).explanation: In a verse by Gamli, Mjöllnir is referred to by the kenning "gorge-whale's [giant's] bane."
Chapter 4 (p.73).quote: While Bilskirnir’s lord [...] did quickly destroy the sea-bed-fish [Midgard ser­pent] with gorge-whale’s [giant’s] bane [Miollnir].

Chapter 17 (p.77).explanation: When Thor is summoned to deal with the drunken giant Hrungnir, he enters the hall with his weapon ready.
Chapter 17 (p.77).quote: Immediately Thor entered the hall with hammer raised up and in great anger...

Chapter 17 (p.79).explanation: During Thor's duel with Hrungnir, Mjöllnir shatters the giant's whetstone and then his skull.

Summary.explanation: A seeress, summoned by the god Óðinn, reveals the history and fate of the cosmos. She describes the creation of the world, the first humans, and a brief "golden age" for the gods. This peace is shattered by greed, war, and the pivotal murder of the innocent god Baldr. The prophecy then turns to the future, foretelling the signs of the final apocalypse: Ragnarök. In a great battle, the gods will fight their enemies—giants and monsters—resulting in their mutual destruction. Óðinn, Thor, and nearly all the gods will perish as the world is consumed by fire and sinks into the sea. Out of the destruction, a new, green world will be reborn from the waves. A few surviving gods and two new humans will repopulate this peaceful world, beginning a new cycle.

Note.explanation: Since the entire narrative revolves around Óðinn, I recommend reading the whole poem. The poem is a combination of numerous shorter poems, is largely gnomic, presenting advice for living, proper conduct and wisdom. It is assumed that it is narrated by Óðinn.

Summary.explanation: Vafþrúðnismál, or "The Lay of Vafþrúðnir," details a deadly contest of cosmic knowledge. The god Odin, seeking to test his own wisdom, travels in disguise to the hall of the ancient and powerful giant, Vafþrúðnir. He challenges the giant to a riddle game where the loser forfeits their head. They quiz each other on the deepest secrets of Norse mythology, from the creation of the world to the end of time. The questions cover the parentage of giants, the names of primordial beings, and the fates of the gods during Ragnarök. Both Odin and the giant answer every question correctly, proving to be intellectual equals. For the final question, Odin asks something only he could possibly know: "What did Odin whisper in Baldr's ear on his funeral pyre?" Recognizing his opponent's true identity, Vafþrúðnir concedes defeat, acknowledging that Odin is the wisest of all beings.

Summary.explanation: Grímnismál, or "The Lay of Grímnir," begins with the god Odin visiting a human king, Geirröðr, in disguise. Believing him to be a dangerous sorcerer, the cruel king captures Odin (as "Grímnir") and tortures him between two fires. After the king's young son shows him kindness by offering a drink, Odin begins a long, prophetic monologue. He reveals a vast wealth of mythological knowledge as a reward for the boy's compassion. He describes the heavenly halls of the gods, the layout of Valhalla, and the structure of the world tree, Yggdrasil. Near the end of his speech, he lists his many names and reveals his true identity as Odin. Horrified at having tortured the chief god, King Geirröðr rushes forward but trips and impales himself on his own sword. His kind son, who helped Odin, then inherits the throne and rules as the new king.

Prose after Stanza 29.quote: Helgi married Sigrún and they had sons; Helgi was not old. Dagr, Hǫgni’s son, sacrificed to Óðinn to avenge his father. Óðinn lent Dagr his spear. Dagr found Helgi, his brother-in-law, at the place called Fjǫturlundr.67 He ran Helgi through with the spear.68 There Helgi fell.69 And Dagr rode to the fell and told Sigrún the news:

Stanza 34.explanation: Dagr blames Óðinn for instigating the family strife that led to him killing Helgi.
Stanza 34.quote:
Dagr said:
‘You’re mad, sister, and out of your mind,
when you invoke an evil fate for your brother!
Óðinn alone is the cause of all the misfortune,
for he bore strife-runes among relatives!

Prose after Stanza 38.explanation: After his death, Helgi is received by Óðinn in Valhǫll.
Prose after Stanza 38.quote: A burial-mound was prepared for Helgi. And when he came to Valhǫll, then Óðinn invited him to rule over all with him.

Stanza 43.explanation: Sigrún compares her joy at seeing Helgi's spirit to the joy of Óðinn's hawks upon finding fallen warriors.
Stanza 43.quote:
Sigrún said:
‘Now I’m as elated at our meeting
as Óðinn’s ravenous hawks,
when they perceive the slain, warm flesh,
or see the dew of blood on the corpse!’

Stanza 50.explanation: Sigrún notes that Helgi must be truly gone, as he has not returned from the afterlife with Óðinn.
Stanza 50.quote:
50. ‘He’d have come by now, if he intended to come,
Sigmundr’s son from the halls of Óðinn;
I expect the hope of the king’s coming is now fading,
since the eagles are screeching on the ash-bough.’

Middle of the prose.quote: Sigmundr carried him a long way in his arms and came to a fjord slender and long, and there was a little ship and a lone man in it. He offered Sigmundr passage over the fjord. But when Sigmundr brought the body out to the ship, then the boat was [fully] laden. The old man said to Sigmundr that he would have to go along the shore inside the fjord. The old man pushed the ship out and vanished at once.

Prose Introduction.explanation: Óðinn is named as one of the three gods involved in the killing of Otr.
Prose Introduction.quote: Reginn offered Sigurðr fosterage and instruction and loved him greatly. He told Sigurðr about his forefathers and those events in which Óðinn and Hœnir and Loki had come to Andvarafors. In that waterfall was a multitude of fish. There was a dwarf called Andvari. He was in the waterfall for a long time in the form of a pike and got himself food there.

Prose after Stanza 5.explanation: Óðinn uses the cursed ring, Andvaranaut, to cover the final part of the otter skin, completing the ransom payment.
Prose after Stanza 5.quote: The Æsir paid Hreiðmarr the treasure and filled up the otter-skin and stood it on its legs. Then the Æsir had to pile up the gold and cover it. And when that was done, Hreiðmarr went forward and saw a whisker, and he told them to cover it. Then Óðinn drew forth the ring Andvaranautr and covered the hair.

Stanza 18.explanation: Óðinn, in disguise on a cliff, introduces himself to Sigurðr and his men using several of his aliases (Hnikarr, Fengr and Fjǫlnir).
Stanza 18.quote:
‘They called me Hnikarr, when young Vǫlsungr
gladdened Huginn, and he had slain;
now you can me “old man from the cliff,”
Fengr or Fjǫlnir — I want to receive passage!’

Stanza 43.explanation: Yggr is an alias for Óðinn.
Stanza 43.quote:
‘I know a battle-being sleeps on the fell,
and the linden’s destruction plays over her;
Yggr pierced her with a thorn: the flax-Gefn
felled men other than [those] he wanted to have.

Stanza 2.explanation: Óðinn is named as the causer of a sleep spell.
Stanza 2.quote:
‘Long I slept, long was I asleep,
long are the misfortunes of men;
Óðinn caused this, that I couldn’t
shake off sleep-staves.’

Prose after Stanza 4.quote: She named herself Sigrdrífa,20 and she was a valkyrie. She said that two kings had fought each other. One was called Hjálm-Gunnarr.21 He was by then old and the greatest warrior, and Óðinn had promised him victory. And the other was called Agnarr, Hauða’s22 brother, whom no one wanted to receive.23 Sigrdrífa felled Hjálm-Gunnarr in the battle. But Óðinn pierced her with a sleep-thorn in revenge for this and told her that she would never win victory in battle thereafter and said that she would marry. ‘But I said to him that I had sworn an oath to the contrary, to marry no man who could be afraid.’

Stanza 13.explanation: Hroptr is an alias for Óðinn.
Stanza 13.quote:
‘Mind-runes you must know if you want to be
of wiser mind than any [other] man;
he read them, he carved them,
Hroptr thought them up,
from the liquid which had leaked
from Heiðdraupnir’s skull
and from Hoddrofnir’s horn.

Stanza 19.explanation: Herjann is an alias for Óðinn.
Stanza 19.quote:
‘I also seemed to the king’s men
higher than any woman of Herjann;
now I am as little as a leaf often is
on(?) bay willows, after the dead boar!

Stanza 8.explanation: Óðinn gets angry with Brynhildr for giving victory to Auða’s young brother.
Stanza 8.quote:
‘Then, in Goðþjóð, I let the old Hjálm-Gunnarr
go to Hel next;
I gave victory to Auða’s young brother —
there Óðinn became extremely angry with me about that.

Stanza 9-10.explanation: Óðinn enclosed her with shields and made her fall asleep until a man without fear could wake her up.
Stanza 9-10.quote:
9. ‘He enclosed me with shields in Skatalundr,
red and white ones — the rims touched;
that man he commanded to break my sleep
who knew how to fear nowhere on land.

10.	‘About my hall, situated in the south,
he let burn the high harrier of all wood;
there he ordered one thane only to ride over it,
the one who fetched me gold, that which lay under Fáfnir.

Stanza 30.explanation: Sigtýr (meaning victory god) is an alias for Óðinn.
Stanza 30.quote:
‘May it go for you, Atli, just as you had
often sworn oaths to Gunnarr and uttered names87 early,
by the south-slanting sun and by Sigt‎ýr’s rock,
by the horse of rest-bedding91 and by the ring of Ullr!’

Note.explanation: Since the entire narrative revolves around Óðinn, I recommend reading the whole poem, and only a summarization of the poem is given here. Synopsis from Wikipedia: Baldr has been having nightmares. Óðinn rides to Hel to investigate. He finds the grave of a völva and resurrects her. Their conversation follows, where the völva tells Odin about Baldr's fate. In the end Odin asks her a question which reveals his identity and the völva tells him to ride home.

Stanza 2.explanation: Herjafǫðr is an alias for Óðinn.
Stanza 2.quote:
‘Let’s ask Herjafǫðr to be in good heart!
He hands out gold and gives it to the worthy;
he gave Hermóðr a helm and a mail-coat,11
and Sigmundr a sword to receive.

Stanza 30.explanation: Baldr’s father and Burr’s heir is Óðinn.

Stanza 44.explanation: Óðinn's fight with Fenrir at Ragnarok is referenced.
Stanza 44.quote:
‘Then comes another, even mightier,
though I dare not name that one;
few now see further ahead
than when Óðinn will encounter the wolf.’

Chapter 4, 9-10 (p.3).explanation: In the euhemerized history tracing the Æsir to Troy, Odin (identified with the name Woden) is described as a wise man with the gift of prophecy who decides to migrate from Turkey (Asia) after foreseeing his future fame.
Chapter 4, 9-10 (p.3).quote: He had a son whose name was Woden, it is him that we call Odin. He was an outstanding person for wisdom and all kinds of accomplish­ments. [...] Odin had the gift of prophecy and so did his wife, and from this science he discovered that his name would be remembered in the northern part of the world and honoured above all kings. For this reason he became eager to set off from Turkey and took with him a very great following...

Chapter 10-11 (p.4).explanation: The text describes Odin's journey as a great king from Asia. He conquers lands in Saxony and Denmark, placing his sons (including an ancestor of Baldr) as rulers. He is welcomed by King Gylfi in Sweden, establishes the city of Sigtunir, and sets up a system of governance modeled on Troy.
Chapter 10-11 (p.4).quote: And whatever countries they passed through, great glory was spoken of them, so that they seemed more like gods than men. [...] There Odin put in charge of the country three of his sons... Odin’s second son was called Beldegg, whom we call Baldr... Then Odin set off north and came to a country that they called Reidgotaland... After that Odin went north to what is now called Sweden.

Chapter 11 (p.5).explanation: Odin continues his journey to Norway, where he sets his son Saeming as ruler. He also brings another son, Yngvi, to Sweden, establishing the Yngling dynasty.
Chapter 11 (p.5).quote: And Odin took with him a son of his whose name was Yngvi, who became king in Sweden, and from him are descended the family lines known as the Ynglings.

Chapter 2-3 and 3-4 (p.8-9).explanation: An alias for Odin is mentioned in a poem. Then when Gangleri asks who the highest god is, he is told of All-father, and his twelve names are listed. And more information is given about him.
Chapter 2-3 and 3-4 (p.8-9).quote:
[…]stones — Svafnir’s [Odin’s] hall-shingles [shields], those
sensible men.

High said: ‘He is called All-father in our language, but in Old Asgard he had twelve names. One is All-father, the second Herran or Herian, the third Nikar or Hnikar, the fourth Nikuz or Hnikud, the fifth Fiolnir, the sixth Oski, the seventh Omi, the eighth Biflidi or Biflindi, the ninth Svidar, the tenth Svidrir, the eleventh Vidrir, the twelfth Ialg or Ialk.’

Then spoke Gangleri: ‘What was he doing before heaven and earth were made?’

Then High replied: ‘Then he was among the frost-giants.’

Chapter 5-7 (p.11).explanation: Odin's origin is described. He is named as the first son of Bor and the giantess Bestla, and brother to Vili and Ve. Together, they are identified as the rulers of heaven and earth and the slayers of the primeval giant Ymir.
Chapter 5-7 (p.11).quote:
He married a wife called Bestla, daughter of the giant Bolthorn, and they had three sons. One was called Odin, the second Vili, the third Ve. And it is my belief that this Odin and his brothers must be the rulers of heaven and earth...

Then High replied: ‘Bor’s sons killed the giant Ymir.

Chapter 8-10 (p.13).explanation: Bor’s sons (Odin being the first) create the human race from wood. Then Odin is described sitting on his high seat, Hlidskialf, from which he can see all worlds. He is also identified as the ultimate patriarch, All-father, from whom the race of the Æsir descends, and the father of Thor by his wife and daughter, Earth.
Chapter 8-10 (p.13).quote:
As Bor’s sons walked along the sea shore,
they came across two logs and created people out of them. The
first gave breath and life, the second consciousness and move
ment, the third a face, speech and hearing and sight; they gave
them clothes and names.

In the city there is a seat called Hlidskialf, and when Odin sat in that throne he saw over all worlds and every man’s activity and understood everything he saw. [...] And this is why he can be called All-father, that he is father of all the gods and of men and of everything that has been brought into being by him and his power. The earth was his daughter and his wife. Out of her he begot the first of his sons, that is Asa-Thor.

Chapter 10-12 (p.14).explanation: As All-father, Odin sets Night and Day in the sky to ride their respective horses.
Chapter 10-12 (p.14).quote: Then All-father took Night and her son Day and gave them two horses and two chariots and set them up in the sky so that they have to ride around the earth every twenty-four hours...

Chapter 12-14 (p.15-16).explanation: Gangleri asks what did the Odin (All-father) did, and he is told that Odin established rules.
Chapter 12-14 (p.15-16).quote:
Then spoke Gangleri: ‘What did All-father do then, when
Asgard was built?’
High spoke: ‘In the beginning he established rulers and bade
them decide with him the destinies of men and be in charge of the
government of the city

Chapter 14-15 (p.17).explanation: As All-father, Odin sacrifices his eye to Mimir to gain wisdom from his well, that is told in a fragment of Völuspa. His horse, Sleipnir, is named first among the Æsir's horses.
Chapter 14-15 (p.17).quote:
All-father went there and asked for a single drink from the well, but he did not get one until he placed his eye as a pledge.


I know it all, Odin, where you deposited your eye, in that renowned well of Mimir. Mimir drinks mead every morning from Val-father’s pledge. Know you yet, or what?


[...]

The names of the Æsir’s horses are as follows: best is Sleipnir, he is Odin’s, he has eight legs.

Chapter 17-19 (p.20).explanation: Odin's hall Valaskialf is named, along with his high-seat Hlidskialf, from which he, as All-father, can see all over the world.
Chapter 17-19 (p.20).quote: There also is a great place called Valaskialf. This place is Odin’s. The gods built it and roofed it with pure silver, and it is there in this hall that Hlidskialf is, the throne of that name. And when All-father sits on that throne he can see over all the world.

Chapter 19-20 (p.21-22).explanation: High identifies Odin as the highest and most ancient of the Æsir, to whom all other gods submit. He is also called All-father and Val-father (father of the slain), and several of his other names (heiti) are listed, followed by a long list of names he gave himself when visiting King Geirrod.
Chapter 19-20 (p.21-22).quote:
‘Odin is highest and most ancient of the Æsir. He rules all things, and mighty though the other gods are, yet they all submit to him like children to their father. [...]


‘Odin is called All-father, for he is father of all gods. He is also called Val-father [father of the slain], since all those who fall in battle are his adopted sons. He assigns them places in Val-hall and Vingolf, and they are then known as Einheriar. He is also called Hanga-god [god of the hanged] and Hapta-god [god of pris­oners], Farma-god [god of cargoes], and he called himself by various other names on his visit to King Geirrod:

“I call myself Grim and Ganglari, Herian, Hialmberi, Thekk, Third, Thunn, Unn, Helblindi, High, Sann, Svipal, Sanngetal, Herteit, Hnikar, Bileyg, Baleyg, Bolverk, Fiolnir, Grimnir, Glapsvinn, Fiolsvinn, Sidhott, Sidskegg, Sig­father, Hnikud, All-father, Atrid, Farmatyr, Oski, Omi, Just-as-high, Blindi, Gondlir, Harbard, Svidur, Svidrir, Ialk, Kialar, Vidur, Thror, Ygg, Thund, Vakr, Skilfing, Vafud, Hropta-Tyr, Gaut, Veratyr.”’

Chapter 21-23 (p.23).explanation: Odin is identified as the father of Baldr.
Chapter 21-23 (p.23).quote: High said: ‘Odin’s second son is Baldr, and there is good to be told of him.

Chapter 25-27 (p.26).explanation: Odin is identified as the father of Vali by the giantess Rind.
Chapter 25-27 (p.26).quote: ‘Ali or Vali is the name of one, the son of Odin and Rind.

Chapter 27-34 (p.27).explanation: As All-father, Odin directs the gods to capture Loki's monstrous children and he deals with them personally, casting the serpent into the sea and Hel into Niflheim.
Chapter 27-34 (p.27).quote: ‘Then All-father sent the gods to get the children and bring them to him. And when they came to him he threw the serpent into that deep sea which lies round all lands... Hel he threw into Niflheim and gave her authority over nine worlds...

Chapter 34 (p.28).explanation: As All-father, Odin sends Skirnir to the dwarfs to have the magical fetter Gleipnir forged for the purpose of binding the wolf Fenrir.
Chapter 34 (p.28).quote: Then All-father sent some one called Skirnir, Freyr’s messenger, down into the world of black-elves to some dwarfs and had a fetter called Gleipnir made.

Chapter 34-35 (p.29).explanation: When Gangleri asks why the Æsir did not simply kill the wolf Fenrir, given the evil he was prophesied to cause.
Chapter 34-35 (p.29).quote: High replied: ‘So greatly did the gods respect their holy places and places of sanctuary that they did not want to defile them with the wolf’s blood even though the prophecies say that he will be the death of Odin.’

Chapter 35 (p.30).explanation: In the description of the goddess Lofn, it is mentioned that she gets leave from All-father (Odin) or Frigg to sanction unions between men and women.
Chapter 35 (p.30).quote: Eighth Lofn: she is so kind and good to pray to that she gets leave from All-father or Frigg for people’s union...

Chapter 35-37 (p.31).explanation: Odin sends his valkyries to every battle to allot death and govern victory.
Chapter 35-37 (p.31).quote: These are called valkyries. Odin sends them to every battle. They allot death to men and govern victory.

Chapter 37-38 (p.32).explanation: Gangleri asks about Val-hall and the fate of the Einherjar. High explains that all men who have fallen in battle since the beginning of the world have gone to Odin in Val-hall.
Chapter 37-38 (p.32).quote: Then spoke Gangleri: ‘You say that all those men that have fallen in battle since the beginning of the world have now come to Odin in Val-hall.

Chapter 38-39 (p.33).explanation: It is explained that Odin himself needs no food; he gives his share to his wolves, Geri and Freki, and subsists on wine alone. His ravens, Hugin and Munin, bring him news from all over the world, earning him the name "raven-god".
Chapter 38-39 (p.33).quote: High said: ‘The food that stands on his table he gives to two wolves of his called Geri and Freki. He himself needs no food: wine is for him both drink and meat. [...] Two ravens sit on his shoulders and speak into his ear all the news they see or hear. Their names are Hugin and Munin. [...] From this he gets the name raven-god.

Chapter 39-41 (p.34).explanation: When asked about the number of people in Val-hall, High declares that Odin is a very great lord to command such a vast troop. A verse from the Æsir themselves is quoted, naming Odin as foremost among the Æsir.
Chapter 39-41 (p.34).quote:
I declare by my salvation that Odin is a very great lord when he commands such a great troop. But what entertainment do the Einheriar have when they are not drinking?’


Thus it says here in the words of the Æsir themselves:

“The ash Yggdrasil, this is the foremost of trees, and Skidbladnir of ships, Odin of the Æsir, of horses Sleipnir..."

Chapter 49 (p.49-50).explanation: After the death of Baldr, Odin is described as taking the loss the hardest, as he best understood the gravity of the event for the Æsir. He directs his son Hermod to ride his horse, Sleipnir, to Hel to ransom Baldr. At Baldr's funeral, Odin attends with Frigg and the valkyries and places his magical ring, Draupnir, on the pyre.
Chapter 49 (p.49-50).quote: But it was Odin who took this injury the hardest in that he had the best idea what great deprivation and loss the death of Baldr would cause the Æsir. [...] Hermod the Bold, Odin’s boy, is the name of the one who undertook this journey. Then Odin’s horse Sleipnir was fetched and led forward... [...] This burning was attended by beings of many different kinds: firstly to tell of Odin, that with him went Frigg and valkyries and his ravens... Odin laid on the pyre a gold arm-ring called Draupnir.

Chapter 49-50 (p.51).explanation: In the narrative of Loki's capture, it is noted that Odin, from his high-seat Hlidskialf, was able to see where Loki was hiding.
Chapter 49-50 (p.51).quote: Then he noticed that the Æsir were only a short distance away from him, and Odin had seen where he was from Hlidskialf.

Chapter 51 (p.54).explanation: Odin's role and fate at Ragnarok are described. He will ride to Mimir's well for counsel, lead the Æsir and Einherjar into battle wearing his golden helmet, and he will fight the wolf Fenrir.
Chapter 51 (p.54).quote: Then Odin will ride to Mimir’s well and consult Mimir on his own and his people’s behalf. [...] Odin will ride in front with golden helmet and fine coat of mail and his spear called Gungnir. He will make for Fenriswolf, and Thor will advance at his side...

Chapter 51 (p.55).explanation: In a verse from Völuspá about Ragnarok, Odin is mentioned speaking with Mimir's head, and later going to fight the wolf.
Chapter 51 (p.55).quote:
Loud blows Heimdall, his horn is aloft. Odin speaks with Mim’s head.


[...]Then Hlin’s second sorrow comes to pass as Odin goes to fight the wolf...

Introduction (p.59).explanation: Odin is listed as one of the twelve Æsir at Ægir's feast. At the banquet, he has bright swords brought into the hall that illuminate the room. He is also one of the three Æsir (with Loki and Hænir) in the story of the giant Thjazi and the abduction of Idunn.
Introduction (p.59).quote:
And in the evening when they were about to start the drinking, Odin had swords brought into the hall and they were so bright that light shone from them...

He began his account where three Æsir set out—Odin and Loki and Hænir...

Chapter 56-57 (p.61).explanation: As compensation to Skaði for her father's death, Odin takes Thjazi's eyes and throws them into the sky, making two stars from them.
Chapter 56-57 (p.61).quote: It is said that Odin, as compensation for her, did this: he took Thiassi’s eyes and threw them up into the sky and out of them made two stars.

Chapter 57-58 (p.62-63).explanation: The origin of the Mead of Poetry is explained. After the dwarfs kill Kvasir, Odin sets out from home to acquire the mead from the giant Suttung.
Chapter 57-58 (p.62-63).quote: Bragi replied: ‘There is this story about it, that Odin set out from home and came to where nine slaves were mowing hay.

Chapter 58, 1, Epilogue (p.64).explanation: The narrative of Odin's acquisition of the mead concludes. He gives the mead to the Æsir and to those skilled in composing poetry. Poetry is thus called "Odin's booty," "his drink," and "his gift."
Chapter 58, 1, Epilogue (p.64).quote: But Odin gave Suttung’s mead to the Æsir and to those people who are skilled at composing poetry. Thus we call poetry Odin’s booty and find, and his drink and his gift and the Æsir’s drink.’

Epilogue, 2 (p.66).explanation: Several kennings for Odin are used in quoted verses, including "All-father," "Hanged-god," and "raven-god."
Epilogue, 2 (p.66).quote:
Now plan I to tell men — long takes my pain to ease — the virtues of the hostile earl — All-father’s malt-surf [the mead of poetry] pounds [resounds].


The host with Hanged-Tyr’s [Odin’s] hoods [helmets] held back...

Often the kind man brought me to the raven-god’s [Odin’s] holy drink...

Chapter 2 (p.67).explanation: Kennings for Odin from various poets are cited, including *Cargo-Tyr*, *Victory-Tyr*, *Gauta-Tyr*, *Hropta-Tyr*, and *Third*. The text also mentions that the land can be called "Odin's wife."
Chapter 2 (p.67).quote:
And Sigurd, he who gave raven-beer [blood] from the flower of the Haddings to Cargo-Tyr’s [Odin’s] swans [ravens]...


It was Victory-Tyr [Odin] himself there in the attacking elf...

Gauta-Tyr [Odin] sent Gondul and Skogul to choose among kings...

‘Hermod and Bragi,’ said Hropta-Tyr [Odin], ‘go to meet the prince...’

The keen wind-steed-[ship-]taker [sea-farer, Earl Hakon] lures under himself [wins] with the true language of swords [battle] the pine-haired deserted wife of Third [Odin...].

Here there is an example of land being called Odin’s wife in poetry.

Chapter 2 (p.68).explanation: Several more kennings for Odin are used in quoted verses: *Ygg*, *Vilir's brother*, *Mim's friend*, *wolf's enemy*, *Slaughter-Gaut*, *Host-Tyr*, and *raven-tester*.
Chapter 2 (p.68).quote:
The land-getter, who binds the mast-top straight [...] Ygg [Odin] won Rind by spells.


I do not worship Vilir’s brother [Odin], god of earth, because I am eager; yet has Mim’s friend [Odin] granted me a grief-comforter...

To you we owe Fal’s cup [the mead of poetry], noble Slaughter-Gaut [Odin]...

I shall succeed in bailing the draught of Host-Tyr’s [Odins] wine-vessel [the mead of poetry]...

Splendid Heimdall rides to the pyre raised by gods for the fallen son [Baldr] of the strangely wise raven-tester [Odin]...

Chapter 2 (p.69).explanation: In a quote from Eiríksmál, Odin is the speaker. Further kennings are used in other verses: *Hropt*, *Hlidskialf's king*, "the speedy one", and "father of mankind".
Chapter 2 (p.69).quote:
In Eiriksmal it says this:


What sort of dream is that, Odin? I dreamed I rose up before dawn to clear up Val-hall for slain people.

I who am young bid the excellent power-wielder of Yngvi’s folk hold over me his quivering bow-land [hand]. Hropt [Odin] took Gungnir.

Hlidskialf’s king [Odin], shy of [reluctant to use] shield, told the man himself his thoughts...

...<the mead of poetry> which the speedy one [Odin] flying bore from Surt’s deep vales.

It is conveyed to me that the son [Thor] of the father of mankind [Odin] was determined soon to test his strength...

Chapter 3 (p.70-71).explanation: In a list of kennings for poetry, one is "Odin's mead." A verse by the poet Egil refers to poetry as "Odin's mead," and a verse by Glum Geirason refers to a poem as a "feast of the gods' ruler [Odin]."
Chapter 3 (p.70-71).quote:
Now examples will be given of how the poets have referred to poetry using such terms as [...] Odin’s mead...

As Egil said:

The prince offered me hospitality; praise is for me a duty. I bore Odin’s mead to the land of the English.

And as Glum Geirason said:

Listen! I begin the feast [the mead, a poem] of the gods’ ruler [Odin] for princes.

I desire silence for Har’s ale [Odin’s mead, poetry]...

Wave of time’s sea rushes before the prince. Rognir’s [Odin’s] deeds [poetry] benefit me.

Hear, Egil, my streams [the mead] of Mim’s friend’s [Odin’s] joy-hill [breast]... Thund’s [Odin’s] find is granted me.

In Vidur’s [Odin’s] booty I use no spite.

Him will I greet with Grim­nir’s [Odin’s] gift.

Chapter 3-4 (p.72).explanation: A kenning for poetry is "Odin’s pot-liquid." Kennings for Thor include "son of Odin and Iord," and "Vidrir’s [Odin’s] heir."
Chapter 3-4 (p.72).quote:
Poetry is called sea or liquid of the dwarfs [...] and hence it is called Odin’s pot-liquid...


How shall Thor be referred to? By calling him son of Odin and Iord...

Chapter 4-5 (p.74).explanation: A primary kenning for Baldr is "son of Odin and Frigg."
Chapter 4-5 (p.74).quote: How shall Baldr be referred to? By calling him son of Odin and Frigg, husband of Nanna, father of Forseti, owner of Hringhorni and Draupnir, enemy of Hod, Hel’s companion, god of lamen­tations.

Chapter 5-8 (p.75).explanation: In a verse by Thord Siareksson, the name *Kialar* [Odin] is used.

Chapter 8-16 (p.76).explanation: A kenning for Týr is "son of Odin." A kenning for Bragi is "son of Odin." Kennings for Vidar include "son of Odin" and "brother of the Æsir." A kenning for Hænir is "Odin’s table-companion or comrade or confidant." A kenning for Loki includes "brother, comrade and table-companion of Odin and the Æsir."
Chapter 8-16 (p.76).quote:

Chapter 16-17 (p.77-78).explanation: Odin is a central figure in the story of the giant Hrungnir. He rides his horse Sleipnir into Jötunheimr and wagers his head against the giant that there is no horse as good. Hrungnir pursues Odin into Asgard, where Odin is said to have invited him for a drink.
Chapter 16-17 (p.77-78).quote: ...but Odin rode Sleipnir into Giantland and arrived at a giant’s called Hrungnir. [...] Odin said he would wager his head on it that there would be no horse as good to be found in Giantland. [...] Odin galloped so hard that he kept ahead... [...] Then Hrungnir replied, looking at Thor with no friendly eyes, and said that Odin had invited him to a drink and that he was under his protection.

Chapter 17 (p.79).explanation: After Thor kills Hrungnir, Odin criticizes Thor for giving the giant's horse, Gullfaxi, to his son Magni instead of to him, his own father.
Chapter 17 (p.79).quote: Then spoke Odin and said it was wrong of Thor to give that fine horse to the son of a giantess and not to his own father.

Chapter 17-18 (p.81).explanation: In a verse from Haustlǫng, "Odin's boy's skull" is a kenning for Thor’s head. In the story of Thor's visit to Geirrod, Loki is said to have flown in "Frigg's falcon form," which implies a connection to Odin's wife.
Chapter 17-18 (p.81).quote: And the hard fragment of the whetstone [...] still stuck in Odin’s boy’s skull...

Chapter 18 (p.83).explanation: In verses from Þórsdrápa, Odin is referred to through kennings such as *flight-ledge-gods' [giants']*, *war-thunder-Gaut [Thor]*, and *Third's [Odin's, Asgard] seat*. His name *Grimnir* is used in a kenning for poetry.
Chapter 18 (p.83).quote:
The sea-thread’s [Midgard serpent’s] father [Loki] set out to urge the feller [Thor] of flight-ledge-gods’ [giants’] life-net from home. [...] when Idi’s yard-visitor [Thor] [...] set out once from Third’s [Odin’s, Asgard] to the seat of Ymsi’s kind [Giantland].


I recite Grimnir’s [Odin’s] lip-streams [mead of poetry].

Chapter 18 (p.84).explanation: More verses from Þórsdrápa use Odin's names in kennings, such as *Gaut's [Odin's] residence* for Asgard and *Iolnir's [Odin's] blaze-wielder* for a warrior.
Chapter 18 (p.84).quote: The most powerful mountain-Hild [giantess] made the sea-Sleipnir [ship] lumber forward, while Hropt’s [Odin’s] helmet-fire-power-investors [berserks] felled her steed.

Chapter 18-22 (p.86).explanation: Primary kennings for Frigg are listed, including "wife of Odin." In the poem Haustlǫng, Loki is referred to as "the helmet-capped educator [Odin] of the fetters," and Odin is also called "the raven-god" in a kenning for Loki.
Chapter 18-22 (p.86).quote:
How shall Frigg be referred to? By calling her daughter of Fiorgyn, wife of Odin, mother of Baldr...

The raven-god’s [Odin’s] friend [Loki] had to blow [the fire].

Chapter 22 (p.87).explanation: In verses from Haustlǫng, Odin is referred to as "the gracious lord of earth" and "the battle-bold Rognir."
Chapter 22 (p.87).quote: The gracious lord of earth [Odin] bade Farbauti’s son [Loki] quickly share the bow-string-Var’s [Skadi’s] whale [ox] among the fellows. But the cunning unyielding oppo­nent of Æsir thereupon snatched up from the broad table four ox-parts.

Chapter 23-24 (p.90).explanation: In a list of kennings for Earth, one is "bride of Odin." A verse by Hallfrod uses the kenning "Baleyg's [Odin's] broad-faced bride" for the land of Norway.
Chapter 23-24 (p.90).quote:
How shall earth be referred to? By calling it [...] bride of Odin...


The guider [earl] of harbour-horses [ships] managed to draw to himself Baleyg’s [Odin’s] broad-faced bride [lord, earth, Norway] by the politics of steel [battle].

Chapter 32-33 (p.95).explanation: The story of Ægir's feast is retold. It mentions Odin's arrival with the other Æsir and how the hall was lit by shining swords, as in Val-hall.
Chapter 32-33 (p.95).quote: Ægir, as was told before, went as a guest to Asgard, and when he was about to return home, he invited Odin and all the Æsir to visit him after an interval of three months. Undertaking this journey were first of all Odin and Niord, Freyr, Tyr, Bragi, Vidar, Loki...

Chapter 34-35 (p.96-97).explanation: In the story of the creation of the gods' greatest treasures, the spear Gungnir is identified as belonging to Odin. Odin, with Thor and Freyr, acts as a judge in the wager between Loki and the dwarfs. He receives the ring Draupnir as one of the treasures.
Chapter 34-35 (p.96-97).quote: After this Loki went to some dwarfs called Ivaldi’s sons, and they made the head of hair and Skidbladnir and the spear belonging to Odin called Gungnir. [...] And when he and Loki produced the precious things, the Æsir took their places on their judgment seats and the decision uttered by Odin, Thor, Freyr was to be final. [...] He gave the ring to Odin and said that every ninth night there would drip from it eight rings equal to it in weight.

Chapter 37-39 (p.99-100).explanation: Odin is a central figure in the story of the Otter's Ransom. He is one of the three Æsir traveling when Loki kills the otter. When captured, he is the one who sends Loki to get the gold and later uses it to pay the ransom to Hreidmar. He keeps the cursed ring Andvaranaut for himself initially.
Chapter 37-39 (p.99-100).quote: It is said that when the Æsir went to explore the whole world – Odin and Loki and Hænir – they came to a certain river... Then Odin sent Loki into the world of black-elves and he came across a dwarf called Andvari. [...] and imposed on him as a ransom all the gold he had in his cave. [...] He went off back to Hreidmar’s and showed Odin the gold. And when Odin saw the ring he found it beautiful and removed it from the treasure, and started paying Hreidmar the gold. [...] Then Odin took out the ring and covered the whisker and declared that they were now quit of the otter-payment.

Hergaut’s [Odin’s]

Chapter 58-60 (p.137).explanation: In a verse by Thiodolf, Odin's name "Gaut" is used in a kenning for a sword ("Gaut's sickle").
Chapter 58-60 (p.137).quote: The prince lets blood-grouse delight in eagle’s barley. The Hords’ king brings Gaut’s [Odin’s] sickle [sword] to the gore-swan’s harvest.

Chapter 60 (p.138).explanation: Odin's ravens, Hugin and Munin, are named. A kenning for a warrior is "troubler of Hugin's food."

The splendid strengthener [feeder] of hostility-gulls [ravens] does wield the splendid gleaming-sun dog [weapon]. The troubler of Hugin’s food [raven] finds an end to his trouble [gets fed].

Chapter 60-61 (p.139).explanation: A kenning for poetry is "Odin's mead" in a verse fragment.

Chapter 65 (p.151).explanation: The origins of names for peoples are traced to Odin.

Chapter 75 (p.156-157).explanation: In comprehensive lists of the gods, Odin's sons are named, and Odin himself (as Ygg) is listed first among the Æsir. His valkyries are also called "Odin's maids".

Stanza 25.explanation: Freyja is referenced through a kenning, "Óðr's wife" (Óðs mey), in the context of the Æsir-Vanir war.

went to their doom-seats and deliberated about it:
who had mingled all the air with mischief,

Chapter 35 (p.29-30).explanation: Od is introduced as the husband of Freyja and father of Hnoss. His long travels are given as the reason for Freyja's tears of red gold and her many names.
Chapter 35 (p.29-30).quote: Freyia is highest in rank next to Frigg. She was married to someone called Od. Hnoss is the name of their daughter. She is so beautiful that from her name whatever is beautiful and precious is called hnossir [treasures]. Od went off on long travels, and Freyia stayed behind weeping, and her tears are red gold. Freyia has many names, and the reason for this is that she adopted various names when she was travelling among strange peoples looking for Od.

gods, and deliberated upon this, who had tainted all the sky

Chapter 18-22 (p.86).explanation: One of the kennings for Freyja is "wife of Od".

Chapter 34-35 (p.29).explanation: Saga is listed as the second highest of the Asyniur, and her dwelling, Sökkvabekk, is named.

53. ‘Hail to you now, Loki, and take the frost-cup
full of ancient mead,

wary and wrathful towards a man;

and then carried them to the cooking-pit;

two of Hymir’s oxen, whole, on his own!

Móði’s father grasped it by the rim,
and through the floor in the hall stepped down;
