Chapter 4,9-10 (p.3).explanation: In the euhemerized account of the Æsir's origins, Thor marries a prophetess called Sibyl, who the text identifies with Sif.
Chapter 4,9-10 (p.3).quote: In the northern part of the world he came across a prophetess called Sibyl, whom we call Sif, and married her. No one is able to tell Sif’s ancestry. She was the most beautiful of all women, her hair was like gold.

Chapter 27-34 (p.26).explanation: Ullr is described as the son of Sif and stepson of Thor.
Chapter 27-34 (p.26).quote: ‘Ull is the name of one, son of Sif, stepson of Thor.

Chapter 4 (p.73).explanation: In a verse by Eystein, Thor is referred to by the kenning "Sif’s beloved".
Chapter 4 (p.73).quote: Sif’s beloved quickly brought out his fishing gear with the old fellow.

Chapter 8-16 (p.76).explanation: A kenning for Ullr is "son of Sif".
Chapter 8-16 (p.76).quote: How shall Ull be referred to? By calling him son of Sif...

Chapter 16-17 (p.77).explanation: A kenning for Loki is "Sif’s hair harmer". In the same chapter, the giant Hrungnir threatens to take Sif and Freyja with him to Jötunheimr.
Chapter 16-17 (p.77).quote:
How shall Loki be referred to? By calling him [...] Sif’s hair-harmer...

And when he became drunk there was no lack of big words: he said he was going to remove Val-hall and take it to Giantland, but bury Asgard and kill all the gods, except that he was going to take Freyja and Sif home with him...

Chapter 18-22 (p.86).explanation: The primary kennings for Sif are listed.
Chapter 18-22 (p.86).quote: How shall Sif be referred to? By calling her wife of Thor, mother of Uli, the fair-haired deity, rival of Iarnsaxa, mother of Thrud.

Chapter 23-24 (p.90).explanation: A kenning for Earth is "mother-in-law of Sif".
Chapter 23-24 (p.90).quote: How shall earth be referred to? By calling it [...] mother-in-law of Sif...

Chapter 30-32 (p.94).explanation: A primary kenning for gold is "Sif’s hair".
Chapter 30-32 (p.94).quote: How shall gold be referred to? By calling it Ægir’s fire and Glasir’s foliage, Sif’s hair...

Chapter 32-33 (p.95).explanation: Sif is listed among the goddesses attending Ægir's feast.
Chapter 32-33 (p.95).quote: Undertaking this journey were first of all Odin and Niord, Freyr, Tyr, Bragi, Vidar, Loki, and then Asyniur, Frigg, Freyia, Gefiun, Skadi, Idunn, Sif.

Chapter 34-35 (p.96-97).explanation: The full story of why gold can be called "Sif's hair" is explained.
Chapter 34-35 (p.96-97).quote: Why is gold called Sif’s hair? Loki Laufeyiarson had done this for love of mischief: he had cut off all Sif’s hair. And when Thor found out, he caught Loki and was going to break every one of his bones until he swore that he would get black-elves to make Sif a head of hair out of gold that would grow like any other hair.

Chapter 45-46 (p.113).explanation: In a verse from the Lay of Biarki, gold is referred to by the kenning "Sif’s scalp-strings".
Chapter 45-46 (p.113).quote: The generous lord pushed, men received, Sif’s scalp-strings...

Chapter 47 (p.115).explanation: "Sif" is used as a kenning for a woman in a verse by Stein.
Chapter 47 (p.115).quote: You will, slender flood-fire-[gold-]keeping Sif [woman], strive against your good fortune like other rods of Hiad­ning’s rocks [gold].

Chapter 50 (p.123).explanation: "Shaking Sif" is used as a kenning for the valkyrie Hild (whose name also means battle).
Chapter 50 (p.123).quote: ...when the ring(-sword) shaking Sif [Hild], filled with malice, brought a neck-ring on to the wind’s horse [ship] to the battle-trunk [warrior].

Stanza 34.explanation: The volva in the poem tells about Sigyn sitting with her bound husband Loki.
Stanza 34.quote:
‘A captive she saw lying under Hveralundr,
like to malevolent Loki in form;
there sits Sigyn, though not at all
well-pleased about her man. Would you know still [more], or what?

Prose Ending.explanation: During the explanation of how Loki was bound, Sigyn is described as sitting by his side with a bowl to stop the venom from dripping on Loki’s face.
Prose Ending.quote: Sigyn, Loki’s wife, sat there and held a hand-basin under the venom.

Chapter 27-34 (p.26).explanation: Sigyn is introduced as Loki’s wife, and Nari or Narfi is named as their son.
Chapter 27-34 (p.26).quote: Sigyn is the name of his wife, Nari or Narfi their son.

Chapter 50-51 (p.52).explanation: Sigyn's loyalty is shown as she tends to the bound Loki, catching the venom from the snake placed above him.
Chapter 50-51 (p.52).quote: But his wife Sigyn stands next to him holding a basin under the drops of poison. And when the basin is full she goes and pours away the poison, but in the mean­time the poison drips into his face. Then he jerks away so hard that the whole earth shakes. That is what you call an earthquake.

Introduction (p.59).explanation: Sigyn is listed among the Asyniur who attend the feast for Ægir.
Introduction (p.59).quote: ...similarly the Asyniur, Frigg, Freyia, Gefiun, Idunn, Gerd, Sigyn, Fulla, Nanna.

Chapter 16-17 (p.77).explanation: In the list of kennings for Loki, one is "husband of Sigyn".
Chapter 16-17 (p.77).quote: How shall Loki be referred to? By calling him [...] husband of Sigyn, enemy of gods, Sif’s hair-harmer...

Chapter 18 (p.83).explanation: A kenning for Loki is "the cargo of incantation-fetter’s [Sigyn’s] arms".
Chapter 18 (p.83).quote: Full of perjury, the cargo [Loki] of incantation-fetter’s [Sigyn’s] arms was on his way sooner with the company’s leader than the battle-Rognir [Thialfi].

Chapter 22 (p.87).explanation: A kenning for Loki is "the burden of Sigyn’s arms".
Chapter 22 (p.87).quote: Then the burden of Sigyn’s arms [Loki], whom all the powers eye in his bonds, got stuck to the ski-deity’s [Skadi’s] fosterer [father, Thiassi].

Chapter 75 (p.157).explanation: Sigyn’s name is mentioned in a list of Asyniur.
Chapter 75 (p.157).quote: Hlin and Nanna, Hnoss, Rind and Siofn, Sol and Saga, Sigyn and Vor.

Chapter 35 (p.30).explanation: Sjöfn is listed seventh among the Asyniur. Her function is to inspire affection and love in people.
Chapter 35 (p.30).quote: Seventh is Siofn. She is much concerned to direct people’s minds to love, both women and men. It is from her name that affection is called siafni.

Chapter 75 (p.157).explanation: Sjöfn is named in a list of the Asyniur.
Chapter 75 (p.157).quote: Hlin and Nanna, Hnoss, Rind and Siofn, Sol and Saga, Sigyn and Vor.

Stanza 11.explanation: This stanza lists the homes of the gods. Skaði's dwelling, Þrymheimr, is mentioned.
Stanza 11.quote:
‘Þrymheimr is the name of the sixth, where Þjazi lived,
that almighty giant;
but now Skaði, the gods’ shining bride, inhabits
the ancient sites of her father.

Stanza 1.quote:
Then Skaði said:
1. ‘Arise now, Skírnir, and go urge10
our boy to speak,
and ask him this: with whom the virile youth
is so very angry!’

Stanza 49-50-51-52.explanation: Skaði threatens Loki after he has insulted the other gods.
Stanza 49-50-51-52.quote:
Skaði said:
49. ‘You’re in a light mood, Loki, [but] you won’t wag
your tail freely like this for long,
because the gods shall bind you on a cliff-edge(?)
with the guts of your frost-cold son!’

Loki said:
50. ‘Know [this], if the gods shall bind me on a cliff-edge
with the guts of my frost-cold son;
I was first and last at the life-loss,
when we laid hands on Þjazi!’

Skaði said:
51. ‘Know this, if first and last you were at the life-loss,
when you laid hands on Þjazi;
from my sanctuaries and fields
cold counsels shall always come to you!’

Loki said:
52. ‘You were lighter in speech to Laufey’s son
when you had me bidden to your bed;
such a matter must be mentioned by us,
if we’re fully to count our faults!’

Prose outro.explanation: Narrates how Loki’s binding happens, and how Skaði puts a snake dripping venom on Loki’s head.
Prose outro.quote:
And after that Loki hid in Fránangrsfors in salmon-form. There the Æsir caught him.

He was bound with the intestines of his son, Nari. But Narfi, his son, turned into a wolf. Skaði took a venomous snake and fastened it up over Loki’s face. Venom dripped from it there. Sigyn, Loki’s wife, sat there and held a hand-basin under the venom. But when the hand-basin was full she carried the venom away, and meanwhile the venom dripped on Loki. Then he writhed at that so hard that all the earth shook; these [tremors] are now called earthquakes.

Chapter 21-23 (p.23-24).explanation: Skaði is introduced as the wife of Njörðr. The story of their marriage and their inability to agree on a home is recounted, with Skaði hating the sea and Njörðr hating the mountains.
Chapter 21-23 (p.23-24).quote: ‘Niord has a wife called Skadi, daughter of the giant Thiassi. Skadi wants to have the home her father had had — this is in some mountains, a place called Thrymheim — but Niord wants to be near the sea. They agreed on this, that they should stay nine nights in Thrymheim and then alternate nines at Noatun.

Chapter 50-51 (p.52).explanation: At the binding of Loki, it is Skaði who places a venomous snake above him to drip poison on his face.
Chapter 50-51 (p.52).quote: Then Skadi got a poisonous snake and fixed it up over him so that the poison would drip from the snake into his face.

Introduction (p.59-60-61).explanation: The narrative of her vengeance and compensation is told. After her father Thjazi is killed, Skaði arms herself and goes to Asgard. The Æsir offer atonement: she may choose a husband from among them by looking only at their feet, and they must make her laugh.
Introduction (p.59-60-61).quote: But Skadi, daughter of giant Thiassi, took helmet and mail-coat and all weapons of war and went to Asgard to avenge her father. But the Æsir offered her atonement and compensation, the first item of which was that she was to choose herself a husband out of the Æsir and choose by the feet and see nothing else of them. [...] It was also in her terms of settlement that the Æsir were to do something that she thought they would not be able to, that was to make her laugh. [...] It is said that Odin, as compensation for her, did this: he took Thiassi’s eyes and threw them up into the sky and out of them made two stars.

Chapter 5-8 (p.75).explanation: In a verse by Thord Siareksson, Skaði is referred to as the "wise god-bride" who could not love the Van (Njörðr).
Chapter 5-8 (p.75).quote: Gudrun became herself her son’s slayer; the wise god-bride [Skadi] could not love the Van...

Chapter 8-16 (p.77).explanation: A kenning for Loki is "wrangler with Heimdall and Skadi."
Chapter 8-16 (p.77).quote: How shall Loki be referred to? By calling him [...] wrangler with Heimdall and Skadi.

Chapter 22 (p.87).explanation: In a verse from Haustlǫng, a couple of kennings for Skaði are used.
Chapter 22 (p.87).quote:
The gracious lord of earth [Odin] bade Farbauti’s son [Loki] quickly share the bow-string-Var’s [Skadi’s] whale [ox] among the fellows.
[…]

Then the burden of Sigyn’s arms [Loki], whom all the powers eye in his bonds, got stuck to the ski-deity’s [Skadi’s] fosterer[…]

Chapter 23 (p.89).explanation: The poet Bragi the Old refers to Thjazi's eyes with a kenning for Skaði.
Chapter 23 (p.89).quote: He who threw into the wide winds’ basin the ski-goddess’s [Skadi’s] father’s eyes above the dwellings of the multitude of men.

Chapter 32-33 (p.95).explanation: Skaði is listed among the goddesses attending Ægir's feast.
Chapter 32-33 (p.95).quote: Undertaking this journey were first of all Odin and Niord, Freyr, Tyr, Bragi, Vidar, Loki, and then Asyniur, Frigg, Freyia, Gefiun, Skadi, Idunn, Sif.

Chapter 75 (p.157).explanation: Skaði is named in a list of the Asyniur.
Chapter 75 (p.157).quote: Now shall all the Asyniur be named. Frigg and Freyia, Fulla and Snotra, Gerd and Gefiun, Gna, Lofn, Skadi, Iord and Idunn, Ilm, Bil, Niorun.

Stanza 20.explanation: Skuld is listed as the third from the Urðr’s spring.

Chapter 15-16 (p.18).explanation: Skuld is introduced as one of the three primary Norns who emerge from the hall by the Well of Weird. Their function is to shape the lives of men.
Chapter 15-16 (p.18).quote: There stands there one beautiful hall under the ash by the well, and out of this hall come three maidens whose names are Weird, Verdandi, Skuld. These maidens shape men’s lives. We call them norns.

Chapter 35-37 (p.31).explanation: Skuld is also identified as a valkyrie, specifically "the youngest norn," who rides with Gunn and Rota to choose the slain in battle.
Chapter 35-37 (p.31).quote: These are called valkyries. Odin sends them to every battle. They allot death to men and govern victory. Gunn and Rota and the youngest norn, called Skuld, always ride to choose who shall be slain and to govern the killings.

Chapter 75 (p.157).explanation: In a systematic list of Odin's maids (valkyries), Skuld is named among them, and the group is explicitly called "norns who shape necessity."
Chapter 75 (p.157).quote: There are yet others, Odin’s maids, Hild and Gondul, Hlokk, Mist, Skogul. Then are listed Hrund and Eir, Hrist, Skuld. They are called norns who shape necessity.

Chapter 35 (p.30).explanation: Snotra is listed thirteenth among the Asyniur. She is described as wise and courteous. The word for a wise person, snotr, is said to derive from her name.
Chapter 35 (p.30).quote: Thirteenth Snotra: she is wise and courteous. From her name a woman or man who is a wise person is called snotr.

Chapter 75 (p.157).explanation: Snotra is named in a systematic list of the Asyniur.
Chapter 75 (p.157).quote: Now shall all the Asyniur be named. Frigg and Freyia, Fulla and Snotra, Gerd and Gefiun, Gna, Lofn, Skadi, Iord and Idunn, Ilm, Bil, Niorun.

Stanza 4-5.explanation: Sól is mentioned as companion of Máni.
Stanza 4-5.quote:
4. ‘Before the sons of Burr lifted up lands,
they who gave shape to glorious Miðgarðr;
the sun shone from the south on the hall’s stones,
then the ground was overgrown with green leek.

5. ‘Sól, companion of Máni, cast from the south
her right hand over the sky-horse-deer(?);
Sól did not know where she had halls,
stars did not know where they had stations,
Máni did not know what might he had

Stanza 22-23.explanation: Óðinn ask Vafþrúðnir where Sól and Máni come from.
Stanza 22-23.quote:
Óðinn said:
22. ‘Say this secondly, if your mind is strong
and you, Vafþrúðnir, know:
whence Máni came, so that he journeys over men,
and Sól the same.’

Vafþrúðnir said:
23. ‘He’s called Mundilfæri, he’s the father of Máni,
and of Sól the same;
they must turn the sky each day,
as a year-reckoning for men.

Stanza 46-47.explanation: Óðinn ask Vafþrúðnir about what will happen after Sól is eaten by Fenrir.
Stanza 46-47.quote:
Óðinn said:
46. ‘Much have I travelled, much have I tried,
much have I tested the powers;
whence will Sól come [back] to the smooth sky,
once Fenrir has destroyed this one?’

Vafþrúðnir said:
47. ‘Álfrǫðull will bear one daughter
before Fenrir destroys her;
that girl must ride, when the powers die,

Sól up from here;
but under their shoulders kindly powers,
Æsir, concealed iron coolers(?).

a shield, [before] the shining god;
I know that rocks and surf shall burn up,
if it falls away from it.

39. ‘Skǫll is the name of the wolf which pursues the shiny-faced god
to the shelter of the wood;
and the other, Hati, he is Hróðvitnir’s son,
he must be before the shining bride of the sky.

Stanza 15-16.explanation: Thor ask Alvíss the different names of the sun.
Stanza 15-16.quote:
15. ‘Tell me this, Alvíss — I expect, dwarf, that you know
all the history of living beings:
what the sun, which the sons of men see,
is named in each world.’

16. ‘It’s named sól among men, but sunna among gods,
dwarves call it Dvalins leiki,
giants eygló, elves fagrahvél,
sons of the Æsir alskír.’

Chapter 10-12 (p.14).explanation: Sol is introduced as the daughter of Mundilfæri. Because of her beauty, the gods became angry and set her in the sky to drive the chariot of the sun. She is relentlessly pursued by the wolf Skoll.
Chapter 10-12 (p.14).quote:
‘There was a person whose name was Mundilfaeri who had two children. They were so fair and beautiful that he called the one Moon and his daughter Sol [sun], and gave her in marriage to a person called Glen. But the gods got angry at this arrogance and took the brother and sister and set them up in the sky; they made Sol drive the horses that drew the chariot of the sun which the gods had created, to illuminate the worlds, out of the molten particle that had flown out of the world of Muspell.

Then spoke Gangleri: ‘The sun moves fast, almost as if she was afraid, and she would not be able to go any faster if she was in terror of her death.’

Then High replied: ‘It is not surprising that she goes at great speed, he comes close who is after her. And she has no escape except to run away.’

Chapter 35-37 (p.31).explanation: Sol is reckoned among the Asyniur.
Chapter 35-37 (p.31).quote: ‘From Gna’s name a thing is said to tower (gnæfa) when it goes high up. Sol and Bil are reckoned among the Asyniur, but their characteristics have been mentioned above.

Chapter 51 (p.53).explanation: It is foretold that during Ragnarok, the wolf will finally catch and swallow the sun.
Chapter 51 (p.53).quote: Then something will happen that will be thought a most signifi­cant event, the wolf will swallow the sun, and people will think this a great disaster.

Chapter 53-54 (p.57).explanation: After Ragnarok, it is prophesied that Sol will have borne a daughter who will take her place and follow her path.
Chapter 53-54 (p.57).quote:
And this also will seem amazing to you, that the sun will have begotten a daughter no less fair than she is, and she shall follow the paths of her mother, as it says here:

A daughter shall Alfrodul bear before Fenrir catches her. She shall ride, when the powers die, the maiden, her mother’s road.

Chapter 25-29 (p.93).explanation: The primary kennings for the sun are listed, which include identifying Sol by her family.
Chapter 25-29 (p.93).quote: How shall the sun be referred to? By calling it daughter of Mundilfæri, sister of Moon, wife of Glen, fire of sky and air.

Chapter 53-54 (p.132).explanation: In a verse by Bragi the Old, a troll-wife refers to herself with a kenning using the sun.
Chapter 53-54 (p.132).quote: ‘Trolls call me moon of dwelling-Rungnir, giant’s wealth-sucker, storm-sun’s bale...’

Chapter 75 (p.157).explanation: Sol is named in a systematic list of the Asyniur.
Chapter 75 (p.157).quote: Hlin and Nanna, Hnoss, Rind and Siofn, Sol and Saga, Sigyn and Vor.

Chapter 35 (p.30).explanation: Syn is listed eleventh among the Asyniur. Her function is to guard the doors of the hall and to be invoked at assemblies in legal defense. The word for a legal denial, *syn*, is said to derive from her name.
Chapter 35 (p.30).quote: Eleventh Syn: she guards the doors of the hall and shuts them against those who are not to enter, and she is appointed as a defence at assemblies against matters that she wishes to refute. Thus there is a saying that a denial (syn) is made when one says no.

Chapter 18 (p.85).explanation: In a verse from *Þórsdrápa*, "Syn" is used as a base-word in a kenning for a giantess.
Chapter 18 (p.85).quote: The beater [Thor] of the frequenter [giant] of hearth-stone-Syn’s [giantess’s] dwell­ing gained victory.

Chapter 47 (p.115).explanation: "Syn" is used as a kenning for a woman in a verse by the poet Steinar.
Chapter 47 (p.115).quote: All dreams of the gentle Syn [woman] of soft necklace-stand [neck] have deceived me. This moving current-sun-[gold-] pillar has put me in the lurch.

Chapter 75 (p.157).explanation: Syn is named in a systematic list of the Asyniur.
Chapter 75 (p.157).quote: Hlin and Nanna, Hnoss, Rind and Siofn, Sol and Saga, Sigyn and Vor. Then there is Var, and Syn must be named, but Thrud and Ran reckoned next to them.

Stanza 39.explanation: Thor says that some women that he killed were she-wolves and that they chased Þjálfi.

Þórr said:
39. ‘They were she-wolves, and scarcely women;
they smashed my ship, which I’d shored up,
threatened me with iron clubs, and chased Þjálfi!

What were you doing meanwhile, Hárbarðr?’

Chapter 44-45 (p.38).explanation: Thialfi is introduced as a peasant's son. He breaks one of Thor's goat's leg bones to get at the marrow. As atonement, he and his sister Röskva become Thor's servants.
Chapter 44-45 (p.38).quote: The farmer’s son was called Thialfi, his daughter Roskva. Then Thor placed the goatskins on the other side of the fire and instructed the peasant and his household to throw the bones on to the goatskins. Thialfi, the peasant’s son, took hold of the goat’s ham-bone and split it open with his knife and broke it to get at the marrow. [...] And when he saw their terror then his wrath left him and he calmed down and accepted from them in settlement their children Thialfi and Roskva, and they then became Thor’s bondservants and they have attended him ever since.

Chapter 46 (p.41-42).explanation: At the court of Útgarða-Loki, Thialfi competes in a running race against a figure named Hugi. He loses three times.
Chapter 46 (p.41-42).quote: ‘Then Utgarda-Loki asked what that young man there could perform, and Thialfi said that he would attempt to run a race of some kind with anyone Utgarda-Loki put forward. He said, Utgarda-Loki, that this was a good feat [...] Then they began the first race, and Hugi was so far ahead that he turned back to meet him at the end of the race.

Chapter 47 (p.45).explanation: Útgarða-Loki reveals that Thialfi's opponent, Hugi, was the personification of Thought, which is why he was impossible to beat.
Chapter 47 (p.45).quote: ‘And when Thialfi competed at running with the one called Hugi [thought], that was my thought, and Thialfi was not likely to be able to compete with its speed.

Chapter 3-4 (p.72).explanation: A kenning for Thor is "lord of Thialfi and Roskva." A verse by Eilif is quoted where Thialfi is called "Roskva's brother."
Chapter 3-4 (p.72).quote:
How shall Thor be referred to? By calling him [...] lord of Thialfi and Roskva...

Eilif said this:

Roskva’s brother [Thialfi] stood enraged, Magni’s father struck a victorious blow. Neither Thor nor Thialfi’s power-stone [heart] shakes with terror.

Chapter 17 (p.78-79).quote:

Chapter 18 (p.83).explanation: In a verse from *Þórsdrápa*, Thialfi is referred to by the kenning "battle-Rognir".
Chapter 18 (p.83).quote: Full of perjury, the cargo [Loki] of incantation-fetter’s [Sigyn’s] arms was on his way sooner with the company’s leader than the battle-Rognir [Thialfi].

Chapter 18 (p.84).explanation: Another verse from *Þórsdrápa* mentions Thialfi accompanying Thor as one of the "pool-riders" [river-crossers].

Stanza 29.quote:
‘Kǫrmt and Ǫrmt and two Kerlaugar,
Þórr must wade them,
every day, when he goes to give judgement
at the ash of Yggdrasill,
because all the god-bridge burns with flame,
holy waters boil(?)

Stanza 51.explanation: Thor is not named, but his sons Móði and Magni will possess his hammer, Mjöllnir after Ragnarok.
Stanza 51.quote:
‘Víðarr and Váli will settle in the gods’ sanctuaries
when the dark flame dies;
Móði and Magni will have Mjǫllnir
and work at the war’s end.

Stanza 33.explanation: Skírnir, threatening the giantess Gerðr, states that Odin, the prince of the Æsir, and Freyr are angry with her, and Asabragr (probably Thor).
Stanza 33.quote:
‘Óðinn will be angry with you, Ásabragr will be angry with you,
Freyr shall loathe you,

the gods’ tribute(?)-wrath!

Summary.explanation: The entire poem is a flyting (insult contest) between Thor and Odin, who is disguised as the ferryman Hárbarðr. Thor, returning from "the east," recounts his battles against giants, including Hrungnir, and against troll-women. Hárbarðr belittles Thor's deeds and boasts of his own exploits. Thor is referred to as "son of Odin," "husband of Sif," and "lord of the goats."

Stanza 23.explanation: Thor says that Midgard would have no humans if he didn’t travel to the east to kill jötnar.
Stanza 23.quote:
Þórr said:
‘I was in the east and I fought giants,
brides skilled in mischief who went to a mountain;
the kindred of giants would be large if all had lived —
there would be no men under Miðgarðr!

What were you doing meanwhile, Hárbarðr?’

Summary.explanation: The poem narrates Thor's quest with the god Týr to fetch a large cauldron from the giant Hymir. Thor's strength is tested when he shatters a goblet by throwing it at Hymir's stone head. The narrative contains the full account of Thor's fishing expedition with Hymir. He uses an ox head for bait and hooks the Midgard Serpent. Thor pulls the serpent from the sea and strikes it with his hammer. The terrified Hymir cuts the fishing line. Thor returns to the gods with the cauldron.

Summary.explanation: Thor awakens to find his hammer, Mjöllnir, has been stolen by the giant Þrymr, who demands Freyja as his bride in return. Following Heimdallr's counsel, Thor disguises himself as Freyja, with Loki as his handmaiden, and travels to Jötunheimr for the "wedding." At the feast, Thor's large appetite for ox, salmon, and mead, and his fierce eyes, arouse suspicion, which Loki explains away. When Mjöllnir is brought forth to consecrate the bride, Thor seizes it and kills Þrymr and all the giants present.

Summary.explanation: The entire poem is a narrative dialogue between Thor and a dwarf named Alvíss ("All-Wise"). Thor returns home to find that Alvíss has come to claim Thor's daughter, Þrúðr, as his bride, an arrangement made in Thor's absence. Thor declares the dwarf can only win his bride by answering a series of questions about the names for Earth, Sky, Moon, Sun, clouds, wind, fire, and other entities as they are known among the different races (men, Æsir, Vanir, giants, elves, and dwarfs). Thor deliberately prolongs the questioning until sunrise. As a dwarf, Alvíss is turned to stone by the daylight.

Chapter 4, 9-10 (p.3).explanation: Thor is euhemerized as Trór, a descendant of the Trojan King Priam. He is described as being raised in Thrace, having hair "more beautiful than gold," and possessing immense strength from a young age.
Chapter 4, 9-10 (p.3).quote: The name of one king there was Munon or Mennon. He was married to the daughter of the high king Priam; she was called Troan. They had a son, he was called Tror; we call him Thor. [...] When he was twelve he had reached his full strength. Then he lifted from the ground ten bearskins all at once and then he killed his foster­father Loricus and his wife Lora or Glora and took possession of the realm of Thrace. [...] Then he travelled through many countries and explored all quarters of the world and defeated unaided all berserks and giants and one of the greatest dragons and many wild animals.

Chapter 8-10 (p.13).explanation: Thor is introduced as Asa-Thor, the first son of Odin and Earth. He is described as possessing power and strength, and as a result, he "overcomes all living things."
Chapter 8-10 (p.13).quote: The earth was his daughter and his wife. Out of her he begot the first of his sons, that is Asa-Thor. [...] And this is why he can be called All-father, that he is father of all the gods and of men and of everything that has been brought into being by him and his power. The earth was his daughter and his wife. Out of her he begot the first of his sons, that is Asa-Thor.

Chapter 20-21 (p.22).explanation: High describes Thor as the most outstanding of the gods, his realm Þrúðvangar, and his hall Bilskirnir. His goats, Tanngrisnir and Tanngnjóstr, and his three great treasures are named.
Chapter 20-21 (p.22).quote: ‘Thor is the most outstanding of them; he is known as Asa-Thor [Thor of the Æsir] or Oku-Thor [driving-Thor]. He is strongest of all the gods and men. [...] Thor has two goats whose names are Tanngniost and Tanngris­nir, and a chariot that he drives in, and the goats draw the chariot. [...] One of them is the hammer Miollnir [...] a girdle of might [...] a pair of iron gloves.

Then the one who was in the rear of the party, which was Loki, said: ‘ “I know a feat that I am quite prepared to have a go at, that there is no one inside here who can eat his food quicker than I.” [...] Loki had then eaten all the meat off the bones, but Logi had also eaten all the meat and the bones too and also the trencher, and it seemed to everyone now that Loki had lost the contest. [...] As they depart, Útgarða-Loki reveals the deceptions, admitting that Thor's true strength terrified him, as his failed attempts had monumental real-world effects (creating the tides, lifting the serpent so high it nearly touched the sky).

Chapter 48 (p.46-47).explanation: The story of Thor's fishing trip to catch the Midgard Serpent is recounted. Thor joins the giant Hymir, uses an ox head for bait, and successfully hooks the serpent.

‘May it go for you, Atli, just as you had
often sworn oaths to Gunnarr and uttered names early,
by the south-slanting sun and by Sigt‎ýr’s rock,

Stanza 5.quote:
‘Ýdalir it’s called, where Ullr has
built halls for himself;
in early days the gods gave Álfheimr
to Freyr as a tooth-fee.

Stanza 42.explanation: Ullr is named in what might make references to an unknown ritual.
Stanza 42.quote:
‘Whoever first takes hold of the fire will have the favour
of Ullr and of all gods,
because worlds become open around the sons of the Æsir,
when the cauldrons are taken off.

Chapter 27-34 (p.26).explanation: Ull is introduced as the son of Sif and stepson of Thor, renowned for his skills in archery and skiing.
Chapter 27-34 (p.26).quote: ‘Ull is the name of one, son of Sif, stepson of Thor. He is such a good archer and skier that no one can compete with him. He is also beautiful in appearance and has a warrior’s accomplish­ments. He is a good one to pray to in single combat.

Introduction (p.59).explanation: Ull is listed among the twelve Æsir attending the feast hosted by Ægir.
Introduction (p.59).quote: Then the Æsir instituted their banquet and twelve Æsir who were to be judges took their places in their thrones and their names are as follows: Thor, Niord, Freyr, Tyr, Heimdall, Bragi, Vidar, Vali, Ull, Hænir, Forseti, Loki...

Chapter 3 (p.70).explanation: A kenning for warriors, "Uli's ash-ship's crew", is cited from the poet Einar Skalaglamm.
Chapter 3 (p.70).quote: There flows over all Uli’s ash-ship’s crew [shield-warriors] who follow him who excites the activity of strife’s defence-trouble [battle] the dwarfs’ mountain-kept liquid.

Chapter 4 (p.72).explanation: A kenning for Thor is "stepfather of Ull".
Chapter 4 (p.72).quote: How shall Thor be referred to? By calling him son of Odin and lord, father of Magni and Modi and Thrud, husband of Sif, stepfather of Ull...

Chapter 4 (p.73).explanation: The name "Ull" is used in a kenning for Thor.
Chapter 4 (p.73).quote: The coal-fish of the earth [Midgard serpent] responded thus, that Ull’s relative’s [Thor’s] fists banged out on the gunwale; broad planks pushed forward.

Chapter 17 (p.80).explanation: Ull's name is used in a kenning for Thor.
Chapter 17 (p.80).quote: All the hawks’ sanctuaries [skies] found themselves burning because of Ull’s stepfather...

Chapter 18 (p.85).explanation: "Uli" is part of a kenning for Thor.
Chapter 18 (p.85).quote: Uli’s splendid stepfather struck the hurting-pin [piece of iron] hard down in the middle of the belt of the fishing-line-way-[sea-]tooth [rock] villain [giant].

Chapter 18-22 (p.86).explanation: Ull's name is used in a kenning for Sif.
Chapter 18-22 (p.86).quote: How shall Sif be referred to? By calling her wife of Thor, mother of Ull, the fair-haired deity, rival of Iarnsaxa, mother of Thrud.

Chapter 36-37 (p.98).explanation: Ull's name is used in a kenning for a shield.
Chapter 36-37 (p.98).quote: The falling sun [gold] of the plain [forehead] of Fulla’s eyelashes shone on the poets’ Ull’s boat-[shield-]fells [arms] throughout the life of Hakon.

Chapter 47 (p.116).explanation: Ull's name is used in a kenning for a shield.
Chapter 47 (p.116).quote: The powerful shield-danger-[sword-]wielding grove with hair for foliage provides Ull’s ash [shield] firs [warriors] in the east with great security.

Chapter 48-49 (p.118).explanation: A shield can be called "Ull's ship".
Chapter 48-49 (p.118).quote: A shield is also called Ull’s ship...

Chapter 49 (p.120).explanation: Ull's name is used in a kenning for a shield.
Chapter 49 (p.120).quote: Ull’s ash(-ship), as here [Thiodolf]: Storms of Ull’s ship rage totally round the prince, where rivet-masts [swords], sheath-rigged, wave.

Stanza 32.explanation: Vali is not named, but is referenced as the brother that was soon born after Baldr’s death, which then avenges Baldr by killing Hǫðr.
Stanza 32.quote:
‘From that tree, which seemed slender,
came a dangerous harm-shaft; Hǫðr shot.
Baldr’s brother was soon born;
that son of Óðinn struck when one night old.

Stanza 11.explanation: After Baldr’s death Vali will be born and avenge Baldr as a one night old.
Stanza 11.quote:
‘Rindr will bear Váli in western halls,
that son of Óðinn will slay when one night old;
he won’t wash his hands or comb his hair
before he bears Baldr’s enemy to the pyre.
I spoke under duress, now I shall be silent!’

Stanza 51.explanation: Víðarr and Vali will survive after Ragnarok.
Stanza 51.quote:
‘Víðarr and Váli will settle in the gods’ sanctuaries
when the dark flame dies;
Móði and Magni will have Mjǫllnir
and work at the war’s end.

Chapter 27-34 (p. 26).explanation: Vali is introduced as a son of Odin and Rind.
Chapter 27-34 (p. 26).quote: ‘Ali or Vali is the name of one, the son of Odin and Rind. He is bold in battles and a very good shot.

Chapter 35-37 (p. 31).explanation: Vali's mother, Rind, is mentioned and counted among the Asyniur.
Chapter 35-37 (p. 31).quote: Thor’s mother Iord and Vali’s mother Rind are reckoned among the Asyniur.

Chapter 50-51 (p. 52).explanation: A different Vali, son of Loki, is mentioned. As part of Loki's punishment, the Æsir transform this Vali into a wolf, who then kills his brother Narfi.
Chapter 50-51 (p. 52).quote: Then Loki’s sons Vali and Nari or Narfi were fetched. The Æsir turned Vali into the form of a wolf and he tore his brother Narfi to pieces.

Chapter 52-53 (p. 56).explanation: It is prophesied that Vali, son of Odin, will survive Ragnarok along with his brother Vidar.
Chapter 52-53 (p. 56).quote: Vidar and Vali will be alive, the sea and Surt’s fire not having harmed them, and they will dwell on Idavoll, where Asgard had been previously.

Introduction (p. 59).explanation: Vali is listed among the twelve primary Æsir who sit as judges at the feast held by the giant Ægir.
Introduction (p. 59).quote: Then the Æsir instituted their banquet and twelve Æsir who were to be judges took their places in their thrones and their names are as follows: Thor, Niord, Freyr, Tyr, Heimdall, Bragi, Vidar, Vali, Uli, Hænir, Forseti, Loki...

Chapter 8-16 (p. 76).explanation: This section explains how to refer to Vali in poetry (kennings). He is called the son of Odin and Rind, stepson of Frigg, brother of the Æsir, the avenger of Baldr, and the enemy and slayer of Hod.
Chapter 8-16 (p. 76).quote: How shall Vali be referred to? By calling him son of Odin and Rind, stepson of Frigg, brother of the Æsir, Baldr’s avenging As, enemy of Hod and his slayer, father’s homestead-inhabiter.

Chapter 75 (p. 156).explanation: Vali is listed as one of Odin's sons.
Chapter 75 (p. 156).quote: Odin’s sons are Baldr and Meili, Vidar and Nep, Vali, Ali, Thor and Hildolf, Hermod, Sigi, Skiold, Yngvi-Freyr and Itreksiod, Heimdall, Sæming.

Chapter 75 (p. 157).explanation: In another list of the most prominent Æsir, Vali is named alongside gods like Ygg (Odin), Thor, and Heimdall.
Chapter 75 (p. 157).quote: Yet shall be listed names of Æsir. There is Ygg and Thor and Yngvi-Freyr, Vidar and Baldr, Vali and Heimdall.

Stanza 39.explanation: When Odinn asks where Njordr came from, Vafthrúdnir responds telling him that “In Vanaheimr wise powers created him”.
Stanza 39.quote:
Vafþrúðnir said:
39. ‘In Vanaheimr wise powers created him,
and gave him as a hostage to the gods;
at the age’s end he will come back
home among wise Vanir.’

Chapter 21-23 (p.23).explanation: The "land of the Vanir" is named as the place where the god Njörðr was raised. It is explained that he was sent from there to the Æsir as a hostage to seal the truce after the Æsir-Vanir War.
Chapter 21-23 (p.23).quote: ‘Niord is not of the race of the Æsir. He was brought up in the land of the Vanir, but the Vanir gave him as hostage to the gods and took in exchange as an Æsir-hostage the one called Hænir. He came to be the pledge of truce between the gods and the Vanir.’

Stanza 30.explanation: The blessing of Vár is invoked by the jötunn Þrymr after his bride (Thor in disguise) is hallowed with Mjǫllnir.
Stanza 30.quote:
Then Þrymr, lord of giants, said this:
‘Bring in the hammer to hallow the bride,
lay Mjǫllnir in the maiden’s lap,
hallow us both together by Vár’s hand!’

Chapter 35 (p.30).explanation: Var is listed ninth among the Asyniur. Her function is to hear the oaths and private agreements made between men and women. She punishes those who break such vows. The word for these contracts, *várar*, is said to derive from her name.
Chapter 35 (p.30).quote: Ninth Var: she listens to people’s oaths and private agreements that women and men make between each other. Thus these contracts are called varar. She also punishes those who break them.

Chapter 22 (p.87).explanation: In a verse from *Haustlǫng*, the name "Var" is used in a kenning for the goddess Skaði ("bow-string-Var").
Chapter 22 (p.87).quote: The gracious lord of earth [Odin] bade Farbauti’s son [Loki] quickly share the bow-string-Var’s [Skadi’s] whale [ox] among the fellows.

Chapter 75 (p.157).explanation: Var is named in a systematic list of the Asyniur.
Chapter 75 (p.157).quote: Hlin and Nanna, Hnoss, Rind and Siofn, Sol and Saga, Sigyn and Vor. Then there is Var, and Syn must be named, but Thrud and Ran reckoned next to them.

Stanza 26.explanation: Loki accuses Frigg of having slept with both brothers of Odinn, Vili and Véi.
Stanza 26.quote:
Loki said:
26. ‘Silence, Frigg! You’re Fjǫrgynn’s daughter,
and have always been man-eager,
since, Viðrir’s wife, you took both
Véi and Vili in your embrace!’

Chapter 5-7 (p.11).explanation: Ve is named as the third of Bor and Bestla, who are the rulers of heaven and earth.

He married a wife called Bestla, daughter of the giant Bolthorn, and they

Chapter 5-7 (p.11).explanation: Vili is named as the second son of Bor and Bestla, who are the rulers of heaven and earth.
Chapter 5-7 (p.11).quote: He married a wife called Bestla, daughter of the giant Bolthorn, and they had three sons. One was called Odin, the second Vili, the third Ve. And it is my belief that this Odin and his brothers must be the rulers of heaven and earth...

Chapter 2 (p.68).explanation: In a verse by Egil Skallagrimsson, Odin is referred to by the kenning "Vilir's brother".
Chapter 2 (p.68).quote: I do not worship Vilir’s brother [Odin], god of earth, because I am eager; yet has Mim’s friend [Odin] granted me a grief-comforter which I count better...

Stanza 53.explanation: Viðarr avenges Odin by killing Fenrir.
Stanza 53.quote:
‘Then comes the mighty son of Sigfaðir,
Víðarr, to fight against the slaughter-beast;
with his hand he lets a sword stand at the heart
of Hveðrungr’s son; then is his father avenged.

Vafþrúðnismál (The Lay of Vafþrúðnir).explanation: Viðarr is named as one of the survivors of Ragnarök who will inhabit the new world.

Stanza 51.explanation: Viðarr and Vali will live after Surtr flame. And Viðarr will avenge his father Odin by killing Fenrir.

Vafþrúðnir said:
‘Víðarr and Váli will settle in the gods’ sanctuaries
when the dark flame dies;
Móði and Magni103 will have Mjǫllnir
and work at the war’s end.

Stanza 53.explanation: Viðarr will avenge Odin by killing the wolf Fenrir.
Stanza 53.quote:
Vafþrúðnir said:
‘The wolf will swallow Aldafǫðr,
Víðarr will avenge this;
he will cleave the cold jaws
of the wolf in battle.’

Stanza 17.explanation: Odin, in disguise, describes the dwelling places of the gods. Viðarr's home is mentioned.
Stanza 17.quote:
‘Overgrown with brushwood and tall grass
is Víðarr’s land, with a wood;
and there the brave youth asserts from his steed’s back
that he will avenge his father.

Prose introduction.explanation: Viðarr is present at the feast where Loki insults the gods.
Prose introduction.quote: To that feast came Óðinn and Frigg, his wife. Þórr did not come, because he was on the east-way. Sif, Þórr’s wife, was there, and Bragi and Iðunn, his wife. Týr was there. He was one-handed: Fenrisúlfr bit off his hand when he was bound. Njǫrðr was there, as was his wife, Skaði, Freyr and Freyja, [and] Víðarr, Óðinn’s son. Loki was there, and Freyr’s servants, Byggvir and Beyla. Many of the Æsir and elves were there.

Stanza 10.explanation: Odin tells Víðarr to give his seat to Loki.
Stanza 10.quote:
‘Arise, then, Víðarr, and let the wolf’s father
sit at the feast,
lest Loki address us with insulting words
in Ægir’s hall!’

Then Víðarr stood up and poured for Loki.

Chapter 27-34 (p.26).explanation: Vidar is introduced as "the silent As," noted for his thick shoe and his great strength, on which the gods rely.
Chapter 27-34 (p.26).quote: ‘Vidar is the name of one, the silent As. He has a thick shoe. He is almost equal in strength to Thor. He is a source of great support to the gods in all dangers.

Chapter 51 (p.54-55).explanation: Vidar's role in Ragnarok is to avenge his father, Odin, by killing the wolf Fenrir. This is described first in prose and then in a verse from *Völuspá*.
Chapter 51 (p.54-55).quote:
The wolf will swallow Odin. That will be the cause of his death. And immediately after Vidar will come forward and step with one foot on the lower jaw of the wolf. On this foot he will have a shoe for which the material has been being collected throughout all time: it is the waste pieces that people cut from their shoes at the toe and heel. [...] With one hand he will grasp the wolf’s upper jaw and tear apart its mouth and this will cause the wolf’s death.

[...]

Odin’s son goes to fight the wolf, Vidar on his way against the slaughterous beast. With his hand he lets his blade pierce Hvedrung’s son’s heart. So is his father avenged.

Chapter 52-53 (p.56).explanation: It is prophesied that Vidar and his brother Vali will survive Ragnarok and dwell in Idavoll.
Chapter 52-53 (p.56).quote: Vidar and Vali will be alive, the sea and Surt’s fire not having harmed them, and they will dwell on Idavoll, where Asgard had been previously.

Introduction (p.59).explanation: Vidar is listed among the twelve primary Æsir who sit as judges at the feast held by the giant Ægir.
Introduction (p.59).quote: Then the Æsir instituted their banquet and twelve Æsir who were to be judges took their places in their thrones and their names are as follows: Thor, Niord, Freyr, Tyr, Heimdall, Bragi, Vidar, Vali, Uli, Hænir, Forseti.

Chapter 8-16 (p.76).explanation: The primary kennings for Vidar are listed.
Chapter 8-16 (p.76).quote: How shall Vidar be referred to? He may be called the silent As, possessor of the iron shoe, enemy and slayer of Fenriswolf, the gods’ avenging As, father’s homestead-inhabiting As and son of Odin, brother of the Æsir.

Chapter 18 (p.82).explanation: The giantess Grid is identified as Vidar's mother.
Chapter 18 (p.82).quote: She was Vidar the silent’s mother.

Chapter 32-33 (p.95).explanation: Vidar is listed as one of the gods attending Ægir's feast.
Chapter 32-33 (p.95).quote: Undertaking this journey were first of all Odin and Niord, Freyr, Tyr, Bragi, Vidar, Loki...

Chapter 75 (p.156-157).explanation: Vidar is named in a list of Odin's sons and in a list of the Æsir.
Chapter 75 (p.156-157).quote:
Odin’s sons are Baldr and Meili, Vidar and Nep, Vali, Ali...

Yet shall be listed names of Æsir. There is Ygg and Thor and Yngvi-Freyr, Vidar and Baldr, Vali and Heimdall.

Chapter 35 (p.30).explanation: Vor is listed tenth among the Asyniur. She is described as wise and inquisitive, so that nothing can be hidden from her.
Chapter 35 (p.30).quote: Tenth Vor: she is wise and enquiring, so that nothing can be concealed from her. There is a saying that a woman becomes aware (vor) of something when she finds it out.

Chapter 75 (p.157).explanation: Vor is named in a systematic list of the Asyniur.
Chapter 75 (p.157).quote: Hlin and Nanna, Hnoss, Rind and Siofn, Sol and Saga, Sigyn and Vor. Then there is Var, and Syn must be named, but Thrud and Ran reckoned next to them.

Stanza 3.explanation: Ymir is mentioned as living early in time.

Stanza 9.explanation: Brimir is a possible alias for Ymir.
Stanza 9.quote:
‘Then all the great powers, the most holy gods,
went to their doom-seats and deliberated about it:
who should devise the lord of dwarves
from Brimir’s blood and from blue limbs.

Stanza 40-41.explanation: It is described how the world was created form parts of Ymir.
Stanza 40-41.quote:
40. ‘From Ymir’s flesh the earth was formed,
and from his “sweat” the sea,
boulders from his bones, trees from his hair,
and from his skull the sky.

41. ‘And from his eyelashes199 the kindly powers made
Miðgarðr for the sons of men,
and from his brain all those hard-hearted
clouds were created.

Stanza 21.explanation: After Odinn ask “whence the earth and sky above first came” and Vafþrúðnir responds.
Stanza 21.quote:
Vafþrúðnir said:
From Ymir’s flesh the earth was formed,
and from his bones boulders,
the sky from the skull of the frost-cold giant,
and from his “sweat” the sea.’

Stanza 28.explanation: After Odinn ask who was the oldest of Ymir’s kin.
Stanza 28.quote:
Óðinn said:
28. ‘Say this as the fifth thing, since they call you wise,
and you, Vafþrúðnir, may know:
who was the oldest of the Æsir or of Ymir’s kin
in early days.’

Stanza 33.explanation: all jötnar are descended from Ymir.
Stanza 33.quote:
‘All seeresses are [descended] from Viðólfr,
all wizards from Vilmeiðr,
message(?)-bearing ones from Svarthǫfði,
all giants are descended from Ymir.

Chapter 4-5 (p.10).explanation: Ymir is introduced as the first being, formed from the dripping rime in Ginnungagap. The frost-giants are descended from him.
Chapter 4-5 (p.10).quote: ...it became the form of a man, and he was given the name Ymir. But the frost-giants call him Aurgelmir, and from him are descended the generations of frost-giants...

Chapter 5-7 (p.11).explanation: High explains that the Æsir do not consider Ymir a god, as he was evil. He sweated a male and female from under his arm, and one leg begot a son with the other, creating the frost-giants. He was nourished by the milk of the primeval cow, Auðhumla. The sons of Bor (Odin, Vili, and Ve) kill Ymir, and his blood causes a great flood that drowns all the frost-giants except Bergelmir and his household.
Chapter 5-7 (p.11).quote:
Then High replied: ‘Not at all do we acknowledge him to be a god. He was evil and all his descendants. We call them frost-giants. The ancient frost-giant, him we call Ymir.’ [...]

Then High replied: ‘Bor’s sons killed the giant Ymir. And when he fell, so much blood flowed from his wounds that with it they drowned all the race of frost-giants...

Chapter 8 (p.12).explanation: The creation of the world from Ymir's body parts is described.
Chapter 8 (p.12).quote:
High said: ‘There is not just a little to be told about that. They took Ymir and transported him to the middle of Ginnungagap, and out of him made the earth, out of his blood the sea and the lakes. The earth was made of the flesh and the rocks of the bones...’

Then spoke Third: ‘They also took his skull and made out of it the sky and set it up over the earth with four points...’

Chapter 8-10 (p.13).explanation: A verse is quoted that summarizes the creation of the world from Ymir's body.
Chapter 8-10 (p.13).quote:
From Ymir’s flesh was earth created, and from blood, sea;
rocks of bones, trees of hair, and from his skull, the sky.

Chapter 14 (p.16).explanation: The dwarfs are said to have first taken shape as maggots in the flesh of Ymir.
Chapter 14 (p.16).quote: The dwarfs had taken shape first and acquired life in the flesh of Ymir and were then maggots, but by decision of the gods they became conscious with intelligence and had the shape of men...

Chapter 18 (p.84).explanation: In a verse from *Þórsdrápa*, the name "Thorn" is used as a kenning for Ymir.
Chapter 18 (p.84).quote: The diminisher of Morn’s children [giants] said his might would grow as high as the world’s roof unless the violent Thorn’s [Ymir’s] neck blood [water] diminished.

Chapter 22-23 (p.88).explanation: In a list of kennings for the sky, one is "Ymir's skull." A verse by Arnor is quoted.
Chapter 22-23 (p.88).quote:
How shall the sky be referred to? By calling it Ymir’s skull and hence giant’s skull...

Never will as generous a young ruler step on to shield-plank [ship] [...] — under Ymir’s old skull.

Chapter 23-24 (p.90).explanation: A kenning for Earth is "Ymir's flesh."
Chapter 23-24 (p.90).quote: How shall earth be referred to? By calling it Ymir’s flesh...

Chapter 24-25 (p.91).explanation: A kenning for the sea is "Ymir's blood."
Chapter 24-25 (p.91).quote:
How shall sea be referred to? By calling it Ymir’s blood...

Out on the sand-bank of good vessels Ymir’s blood roars.

Chapter 73-75 (p.155).explanation: Ymir is named first in a systematic list of giants.
Chapter 73-75 (p.155).quote: I shall tell the names of giants. Ymir, Gang and Mimir, Idi and Thiassi, Hrungnir...
